description: The CompTIA Advanced Security Practitioner (CASP) certification designates IT professionals with advanced-level security skills and knowledge. CASP covers the technical knowledge and skills required to conceptualize, design, and engineer secure solutions across complex enterprise environments. CASP is approved by U.S. Dept. of Defense to meet IA technical and management certification requirements.
name: CompTIA Advanced Security Practitioner
subtitle: CASP

episodes.description: Those looking to complete the CompTIA Advanced Security Practitioner (CASP) certification will find in this course an overview of the process in achieving the certification and a brief amount of details about the exam required to pass in order to receive the certification. The certification is designed for advanced security professionals that have knowledge of Security+, have a few years of experience in the field, and will go on to learn more advanced skills for those who are going to be managing and need to understand things like risk management and incident response.

episodes.description: A hashing algorithm does not encrypt the original plain text, but generates a fixed length value and a unique set of characters for the inserted plain text. The hashing algorithm is not designed to be reversed and fits into the area of integrity, but also plays a role in non-repudiation. episodes.description: In today's world, encryption is taking a bigger and bigger role in society as security issues become more prevalent. Cryptographic solutions are just different ways one can combine the things cryptography provides to get something that's going to address a certain problem. episodes.description: A firewall is a device that blocks all ports except for designated traffic that a user wants to allow on their network. Viewers will hear about different types of firewalls, where they should be put within a network, and how to test them to make sure they are set up properly.
episodes.title: Firewalls and ACLs

at this point in our careers, studying for

with what a firewall is.

12

block all those ports.

13
00:00:42.895 --> 00:00:46.450
We have 65,535 of those guys.

14

block all those ports and

16

17

traffic between two zones,

18

19
00:01:05.920 --> 00:01:10.510
One's got a higher or lower security level

20
00:01:10.510 --> 00:01:14.490

21
00:01:14.490 --> 00:01:18.469

22

23

Everything from the basic packet
filtering stuff that just looks at where

24
00:01:27.955 --> 00:01:32.776

important protocol, that,

25
00:01:32.776 --> 00:01:36.987
all the way up to the application
layer and all that good stuff.

26
00:01:36.987 --> 00:01:41.723
And there's different things
happen at each one of the levels.

27
00:01:41.723 --> 00:01:46.767
And they all offer you something
that the other one doesn't,

28
00:01:46.767 --> 00:01:51.522

29
00:01:51.522 --> 00:01:57.670
So that's what a firewall is,

00:01:57.670 --> 00:02:00.400

35
00:02:14.925 --> 00:02:19.405
I mean there's examples of Linux distros

36

That's another variation of it.

to block off certain areas

00:05:04.730 --> 00:05:07.150

00:05:07.150 --> 00:05:10.745

00:05:24.140 --> 00:05:26.038
And so they need to manipulate those.

00:05:26.038 --> 00:05:28.121
And then there's even firewalls and

00:05:31.630 --> 00:05:35.830

And then you even see them

00:05:40.950 --> 00:05:46.070

00:05:57.548 --> 00:05:59.630

00:06:02.830 --> 00:06:05.950
If that's the case,

00:06:05.950 --> 00:06:08.730

00:06:08.730 --> 00:06:12.080
there's gonna probably be a firewall or

That there's only certain things

00:06:21.310 --> 00:06:26.380

00:06:53.925 --> 00:06:58.025

There's different opinions

00:07:14.270 --> 00:07:18.970
Some people might actually put, instead

00:07:18.970 --> 00:07:22.340

00:07:22.340 --> 00:07:25.330
They might say, okay, the outer firewall,

00:07:30.579 --> 00:07:34.990

00:07:34.990 --> 00:07:37.420
and everything else they

00:07:37.420 --> 00:07:41.060
if it can get past it,

00:07:41.060 --> 00:07:44.996
But then you have that other firewall
on the other side of that DMZ or

00:07:44.996 --> 00:07:49.094
screen subnet where stuff can't
get through into the main network.

00:07:49.094 --> 00:07:55.305

which one you use, a router with its ACLs,

00:07:55.305 --> 00:08:00.117
or firewalls with its rules and
all the stuff that goes with that,

126
00:08:00.117 --> 00:08:04.020
It's kind of almost like
a personal taste thing.

00:08:04.020 --> 00:08:09.450

00:08:15.280 --> 00:08:21.350
A router I use if maybe I had

that's just one of

00:08:46.500 --> 00:08:48.340

clicking away, doing your stuff and

379
00:23:29.562 --> 00:23:33.866
they're able just to readily
extract this through the API and

380
00:23:33.866 --> 00:23:37.423
bring it into here and
display it for us to browse and

381
00:23:37.423 --> 00:23:42.009
laugh at people on their vacation and
what ever else we want to do.

382
00:23:42.009 --> 00:23:45.307
And you'd be amazed,
both in a good and bad way,

383
00:23:45.307 --> 00:23:48.209
about the stuff that people post on there.

384
00:23:48.209 --> 00:23:52.797
And think that I'm in my own
part of the Internet and

385
00:23:52.797 --> 00:23:59.210
no one's gonna be able to find it
because there's this big sea of data.

386
00:23:59.210 --> 00:23:59.740
Yeah.

387
00:23:59.740 --> 00:24:03.235
You've got another thing coming if that's
what you think that's gonna happen.

388
00:24:03.235 --> 00:24:09.730
Notice I didn't just liberally start
scrolling through this like crazy.

389
00:24:09.730 --> 00:24:12.600
Because I do not want to
have to rerecord this.

390
00:24:12.600 --> 00:24:15.910
I do not want to get yelled at for
something showing up there.

391
00:24:15.910 --> 00:24:18.880
Because I've had some stuff where
it scrolled through it when I

392
00:24:18.880 --> 00:24:22.320
tried the stuff out, and
we're like eye bleach.

393
00:24:22.320 --> 00:24:23.917
Get that out of here.

394
00:24:23.917 --> 00:24:27.590
>> [LAUGH]
>> I wanted to gouge my eyes out.

395
00:24:27.590 --> 00:24:30.470
And some of these things people you can
tell they thought well no one's ever going

396
00:24:30.470 --> 00:24:31.090
to find it.

397
00:24:31.090 --> 00:24:33.130
Well someone's gonna find it.

398
00:24:33.130 --> 00:24:34.132
>> Absolutely.

399
00:24:34.132 --> 00:24:38.910
And then input validation is another
big one that we've got to deal with.

400
00:24:38.910 --> 00:24:42.875
>> Yeah so we don't need to worry about
the geo tagging, so that's one with that.

401
00:24:42.875 --> 00:24:45.895
We have other things that
can cause nastiness, and

402
00:24:45.895 --> 00:24:48.495
one of them is input validation.

403
00:24:48.495 --> 00:24:50.055
Input validation is just like it sounds.

404
00:24:50.055 --> 00:24:52.425
It's you put something
into an application and

405
00:24:52.425 --> 00:24:55.305
there's a mechanism to validate
that it was in the correct format.

406
00:24:55.305 --> 00:24:57.845
Okay, that's easy enough, right?

407
00:24:57.845 --> 00:24:59.235
It's straightforward.

408
00:24:59.235 --> 00:25:01.995
It seems like there's nothing
really more to add to that.

409
00:25:01.995 --> 00:25:03.465
There is more to add to that.

410
00:25:03.465 --> 00:25:09.340
What we have to add onto that is the fact
that when you do input validation or

411
00:25:09.340 --> 00:25:14.320
a lack of input validation it leads
to other stuff that could be big,

412
00:25:14.320 --> 00:25:16.314
nasty things for you to have to deal with.

413
00:25:16.314 --> 00:25:20.234
For example, SQL injections.

414
00:25:20.234 --> 00:25:22.930
SQL injections.

415
00:25:22.930 --> 00:25:27.860
They are largely enabled by having
a lack of input validation or

416
00:25:27.860 --> 00:25:29.590
poor input validation.

417
00:25:29.590 --> 00:25:33.290
And so if you are doing it correctly and

418
00:25:33.290 --> 00:25:36.380
someone can monkey around
with fields on a form.

419
00:25:36.380 --> 00:25:41.080
They can construct queries right through
that form that you kindly provided them,

420
00:25:41.080 --> 00:25:44.660
and start getting information out of that.

421
00:25:44.660 --> 00:25:45.740
That's like design 101.

422
00:25:45.740 --> 00:25:49.720
I would think with design applications
they would tell you, hey, if you put

423
00:25:49.720 --> 00:25:54.520
a form out there, don't you have an idea
of what type of information you want back?

424
00:25:54.520 --> 00:25:59.350
If you do, then you put restrictions
on it to make sure it's only that, so

425
00:25:59.350 --> 00:26:04.940
people can't do all this nastiness
with it or do it as easily as we see.

426
00:26:04.940 --> 00:26:08.920
There's that, then there's even
the unexpected outside of SQLl injection.

427
00:26:08.920 --> 00:26:11.930
There's even something
a technique called fuzzing.

428
00:26:11.930 --> 00:26:17.330
And what fuzzing does it feed
ranges of values to something.

429
00:26:17.330 --> 00:26:20.860
And you can tell there's
actually utilities that do this.

430
00:26:20.860 --> 00:26:24.660
You can feed it ranges of value and
see how the application reacts.

431
00:26:24.660 --> 00:26:31.840
And then based on how it reacts
you can determine if there's

432
00:26:31.840 --> 00:26:36.960
something you have to do to shore
up the application or fix it.

433
00:26:36.960 --> 00:26:42.040
Fuzzing can reveal some very
interesting results that

434
00:26:42.040 --> 00:26:47.020
you would not expect because you may not
try these weird combinations of things.

435
00:26:47.020 --> 00:26:51.230
And I can tell you from working
in the area of testing software

436
00:26:51.230 --> 00:26:56.190
applications as one of my job
responsibilities years ago,

437
00:26:56.190 --> 00:26:59.645
the stuff that before
fuzzy became a thing.

438
00:26:59.645 --> 00:27:04.735
People were doing the crude,
brute force version of fuzzing.

439
00:27:04.735 --> 00:27:10.085
I remember I worked with people in Japan,
and I don't know what it is about

440
00:27:10.085 --> 00:27:14.835
the Japanese, they were very good at this,
they had some extra sense or whatever

441
00:27:14.835 --> 00:27:19.243
to be able to do this, because the people
we worked with over there, they were

442
00:27:19.243 --> 00:27:23.255
constantly sending us stuff, it's like,
oh well do this and watch what comes out.

443
00:27:25.070 --> 00:27:27.710
What possessed you to do that?

444
00:27:27.710 --> 00:27:29.230
That was what came to mind.

445
00:27:29.230 --> 00:27:30.870
What possessed you to do that?

446
00:27:30.870 --> 00:27:32.870
I'm not saying that this
isn't a good catch,

447
00:27:32.870 --> 00:27:36.740
but we have a lot of brain power over
here that never thought of that.

448
00:27:36.740 --> 00:27:39.620
You did that on your own, so
you've got to tell us what the secret is.

449
00:27:39.620 --> 00:27:40.265
>> It was my cat.

450
00:27:40.265 --> 00:27:41.190
>> [LAUGH]
>> Yeah,

451
00:27:41.190 --> 00:27:44.460
they just put it on the keyboard and
stomp around.

452
00:27:44.460 --> 00:27:47.140
They come up with this thing.

453
00:27:47.140 --> 00:27:47.700
What did you?

454
00:27:47.700 --> 00:27:48.750
What are you doing?

455
00:27:48.750 --> 00:27:54.800
Some of the results that they
would get just by punching

456
00:27:54.800 --> 00:28:00.090
in some stuff that was
not entirely random but

457
00:28:00.090 --> 00:28:07.060
that someone could easily put
that in just by accident.

458
00:28:07.060 --> 00:28:09.290
But it probably unlikely.

459
00:28:09.290 --> 00:28:13.010
It would open doors and show you,
oh well, that's apt to actually happen.

460
00:28:13.010 --> 00:28:14.430
Let me open up a code, wait a minute,

461
00:28:14.430 --> 00:28:16.390
there's something else in
here that can be done.

462
00:28:16.390 --> 00:28:20.820
Let me fix that code before any
of these other bad things happen.

463
00:28:20.820 --> 00:28:23.950
Which may be more likely,
so that was a good thing.

464
00:28:23.950 --> 00:28:29.572
But yeah, I swear it still sticks
with me that my Japanese friends over

465
00:28:29.572 --> 00:28:35.408
there that they were able to just,
it was like a magical ability I swear.

466
00:28:35.408 --> 00:28:39.249
They had like divining rods or something
doing that because there had to be some

467
00:28:39.249 --> 00:28:42.344
mystical power going on that I
don't know about that they had.

468
00:28:42.344 --> 00:28:44.694
>> [LAUGH]
>> All right well Sean,

469
00:28:44.694 --> 00:28:46.944
tell you what there was a lot
of great information on.

470
00:28:46.944 --> 00:28:50.423
Again, more application, in this case,
specific application issues that we've

471
00:28:50.423 --> 00:28:53.620
gotta deal with, that we've gotta be
able to protect our networks against.

472
00:28:53.620 --> 00:28:56.190
And we've gotta think about
when we're designing a good,

473
00:28:56.190 --> 00:29:01.040
secure network and machines and
the application that are running on those.

474
00:29:01.040 --> 00:29:03.840
Anything else you wanna throw in
here before we wrap this one up?

475
00:29:03.840 --> 00:29:10.400
>> No, I think we covered a pretty airly

476
00:29:10.400 --> 00:29:14.410
decent range of things that can
happen in web applications.

477
00:29:14.410 --> 00:29:14.990
Like I said,

478
00:29:14.990 --> 00:29:19.440
do not think that it's on that strictly
limited to what you have here.

479
00:29:19.440 --> 00:29:25.290
These just happen to be the things
that CompTL likes to hit on but

480
00:29:25.290 --> 00:29:28.760
there's plenty of other ones so
I don't want you to take away from this

481
00:29:28.760 --> 00:29:32.390
that if you're someone that's watching
this and as a web developer and

482
00:29:32.390 --> 00:29:35.780
you're Shawn and
Mike just missed an opportunity

483
00:29:35.780 --> 00:29:39.190
to talk about a whole nuch of other
nasty ones out there that happened.

484
00:29:39.190 --> 00:29:41.440
Well, we're well aware,
first of all we're not developers,

485
00:29:41.440 --> 00:29:44.300
we're not trying to work
on it at that level.

486
00:29:44.300 --> 00:29:46.110
Second of all, there's only so

487
00:29:46.110 --> 00:29:49.720
many that can be tested on to make
sure you have an awareness of it, and

488
00:29:49.720 --> 00:29:53.200
these things actually make you aware
of some of the things that can happen.

489
00:29:53.200 --> 00:29:56.390
And hopefully when you're doing your
testing and planning, and doing

490
00:29:56.390 --> 00:30:00.710
your design as a CASP, as that management
person, this has opened your eyes.

491
00:30:00.710 --> 00:30:06.320
It's like I'd better take a closer look at
this stuff because I know there's this and

492
00:30:06.320 --> 00:30:08.330
there's probably other stuff,
and you'd be right.

493
00:30:08.330 --> 00:30:10.010
You just have to do your research.

494
00:30:10.010 --> 00:30:10.880
>> All right, good.

495
00:30:10.880 --> 00:30:13.670
All right, well ladies and gentlemen,
that's gonna do it for this episode.

496
00:30:13.670 --> 00:30:15.870
Signing off for ITProTV, I'm Mike Rodrick.

episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.623
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10.623 --> 00:00:14.590
Hello and welcome to another episode
of ITProTV, I'm your host Mike Rodrick.

3
00:00:14.590 --> 00:00:16.221
With me today is Mr. Sean Oriyano.

4
00:00:16.221 --> 00:00:17.420
How you doing Sean?

5
00:00:17.420 --> 00:00:18.780
>> I'm doing pretty good,
how are you doing?

6
00:00:18.780 --> 00:00:20.520
>> I'm doing great, excited to be here.

7
00:00:20.520 --> 00:00:24.260
We got another of our CompTIA
advanced security practitioner

8
00:00:24.260 --> 00:00:25.190
episodes coming your way.

9
00:00:25.190 --> 00:00:29.200
And in this one we're going to look at
something called application sandboxing.

10
00:00:29.200 --> 00:00:33.290
And Sean, I don't think we're talking
about taking our applications outside and

11
00:00:33.290 --> 00:00:34.550
playing with them in the sandbox.

12
00:00:34.550 --> 00:00:37.340
So, what are we talking about here?

13
00:00:37.340 --> 00:00:39.940
>> I would do that, that's a great idea.

14
00:00:39.940 --> 00:00:41.225
>> Have a little Tonka truck.

15
00:00:41.225 --> 00:00:42.686
>> [LAUGH]
>> Some little matchbox cars,

16
00:00:42.686 --> 00:00:43.482
we're good to go.

17
00:00:43.482 --> 00:00:46.692
>> Hey, you know, after doing all this
stuff it's probably a good break.

18
00:00:46.692 --> 00:00:53.895
[LAUGH] Yeah well I mean we're definitely
not talking something like that, but

19
00:00:53.895 --> 00:00:59.320
when we talk about sandboxing,
sandboxing is a technique they use,

20
00:00:59.320 --> 00:01:01.990
and there's several different
ways to implement it.

21
00:01:01.990 --> 00:01:07.130
But it all comes down to a way
to kind of compartmentalize, or

22
00:01:07.130 --> 00:01:12.380
enclose an application and
wrap it in such a way that it has its

23
00:01:12.380 --> 00:01:17.280
access restricted to what's
outside in the big wide world.

24
00:01:17.280 --> 00:01:22.860
So, we're doing it for security reasons
of course, because by doing this we

25
00:01:24.060 --> 00:01:30.690
can perhaps stop the spread
of things like malware.

26
00:01:30.690 --> 00:01:34.740
We could stop things from
accessing what's in other boxes or

27
00:01:34.740 --> 00:01:39.430
other areas of the system that might
be more sensitive information.

28
00:01:39.430 --> 00:01:44.640
We can just do some interesting
stuff there to really restrict

29
00:01:44.640 --> 00:01:46.718
what's happening in control access.

30
00:01:46.718 --> 00:01:50.070
>> So it's kinda like isolating
the application then,

31
00:01:50.070 --> 00:01:51.510
in its own little environment.

32
00:01:51.510 --> 00:01:55.621
And I almost don't have to worry about
outside influences and things like that.

33
00:01:55.621 --> 00:02:01.367
>> Yeah, that's exactly what you would
have by doing something like this,

34
00:02:01.367 --> 00:02:05.269
and you do see this in
a number of different cases.

35
00:02:05.269 --> 00:02:10.417
I mean, ones that immediately
come to mind would be

36
00:02:10.417 --> 00:02:16.730
stuff like the browser in
Windows from Vista forward.

37
00:02:16.730 --> 00:02:21.205
There's a mode in there on the 64-bit side
where you can, in essence, have it running

38
00:02:21.205 --> 00:02:24.664
in a sandbox where it's got it's own
little piece of the registry and

39
00:02:24.664 --> 00:02:27.075
it's got a piece of
the system it has access to.

40
00:02:27.075 --> 00:02:29.641
And that's all locked down
to just those things,

41
00:02:29.641 --> 00:02:32.080
unless you decide to turn it off that is.

42
00:02:32.080 --> 00:02:36.470
It's got those, but
then you also have another notable

43
00:02:36.470 --> 00:02:40.820
side of this is the isolation or
sandboxing that happens with Java.

44
00:02:40.820 --> 00:02:43.435
Java as a language
implements that as well.

45
00:02:43.435 --> 00:02:49.420
Where, unless you do something special,
basically signing your application,

46
00:02:49.420 --> 00:02:54.230
using the digital signature technology
to verify where it came from and

47
00:02:54.230 --> 00:02:57.250
that someone's on the level,
it puts it in the sandbox.

48
00:02:57.250 --> 00:03:00.810
So the stuff running in that
machine is kept enclosed and

49
00:03:00.810 --> 00:03:05.620
isolated so it doesn't really get
a lot of access to the outside world.

50
00:03:05.620 --> 00:03:09.840
It has to kind of, it can do a few things,
but it's extremely limited.

51
00:03:09.840 --> 00:03:12.350
But those would be
a couple examples of it.

52
00:03:12.350 --> 00:03:16.461
But I think it's kind of also
important here to maybe make

53
00:03:16.461 --> 00:03:19.898
a distinction when you
talk about sandboxing.

54
00:03:19.898 --> 00:03:24.768
Because you use the term isolation, and
the description I'm using also could

55
00:03:24.768 --> 00:03:28.457
be something that could be
a situation where you're like,

56
00:03:28.457 --> 00:03:32.177
is he talking virtualization or
is he talking sandboxing?

57
00:03:32.177 --> 00:03:37.240
There can be some confusion there and
in a lot of cases they're the same,

58
00:03:37.240 --> 00:03:42.510
but there's other situations where
they're decidedly different.

59
00:03:42.510 --> 00:03:46.800
Sandboxing, as we're talking here,
is more along the lines of

60
00:03:46.800 --> 00:03:50.598
doing an individual application and
really doing the isolation at that level.

61
00:03:50.598 --> 00:03:55.660
And really restricting what happens,
if anything happens at all,

62
00:03:55.660 --> 00:03:59.950
between the two sides of what's
inside the box and what's outside.

63
00:03:59.950 --> 00:04:03.260
Virtualization, you tend to have

64
00:04:03.260 --> 00:04:07.290
more control without having to do
too much of the special things.

65
00:04:07.290 --> 00:04:12.070
You'd still have more control over what
level of access you can do either way.

66
00:04:12.070 --> 00:04:17.540
Some virtualization systems like Hyper-V,
you can't, for example,

67
00:04:17.540 --> 00:04:23.660
drag and drop between the host and
the guest, but you can set up stuff like

68
00:04:23.660 --> 00:04:28.100
sharing of the files on the system that
makes you kind of go through that one.

69
00:04:28.100 --> 00:04:30.340
But there's other ones that
don't take that into account.

70
00:04:30.340 --> 00:04:34.940
They're isolated but you can drag and
drop back and forth, and so

71
00:04:34.940 --> 00:04:39.790
it's not as rigidly enforcing
the isolation as the other ones would.

72
00:04:39.790 --> 00:04:44.017
So we're talking more about, like I said,
stuff at the application level,

73
00:04:44.017 --> 00:04:45.003
stuff like that.

74
00:04:45.003 --> 00:04:49.490
But the term sandboxing, to be quite
honest, is used quite liberally.

75
00:04:49.490 --> 00:04:55.880
You'll hear that term used all over
the place and, what can you say?

76
00:04:55.880 --> 00:05:01.920
As long as you've got the basic concept
down that you're putting something

77
00:05:01.920 --> 00:05:08.060
in this box and giving it its own area to
play in, hence the term [LAUGH] sandbox.

78
00:05:08.060 --> 00:05:11.421
Then you're pretty much in
the right zip code, I guess.

79
00:05:11.421 --> 00:05:15.815
>> Gotcha, and then so you've got the
different models that we can do with our

80
00:05:15.815 --> 00:05:20.685
sandbox, like you mentioned with that
application or through virtualization.

81
00:05:20.685 --> 00:05:25.240
>> Yeah, you can use it
those two ways and, in fact,

82
00:05:25.240 --> 00:05:31.530
I mentioned just to put
a kind of a spin on this.

83
00:05:31.530 --> 00:05:35.180
I just told you,
Java uses that sandboxing model so

84
00:05:35.180 --> 00:05:37.730
when you're running something
in the browser or on the system

85
00:05:37.730 --> 00:05:42.368
it's got that box around it unless the
developer decides to digitally sign it.

86
00:05:42.368 --> 00:05:48.100
Well, Iguess what they call the stuff
that runs Java on an individual system.

87
00:05:48.100 --> 00:05:50.120
They call them JVMs,
Java Virtual Machines.

88
00:05:50.120 --> 00:05:53.580
So I just told you it uses the sandbox,
and I'm telling you, oh, virtualization,

89
00:05:53.580 --> 00:05:57.690
sandboxing, there's some similarities,
but there's also differences there too.

90
00:05:57.690 --> 00:06:00.550
Well, that just really just messed you
up cuz I went through and said, oh,

91
00:06:00.550 --> 00:06:03.585
well Java uses sandboxing, but
they've got Java Virtual Machines.

92
00:06:03.585 --> 00:06:07.155
What, what is that?

93
00:06:07.155 --> 00:06:09.474
It's terminology, right?

94
00:06:09.474 --> 00:06:12.214
They can decide to change the game on you,
and

95
00:06:12.214 --> 00:06:15.830
that's what they kinda played
around with a bit there.

96
00:06:15.830 --> 00:06:17.920
>> So is it something that I
can do with any application?

97
00:06:17.920 --> 00:06:21.230
Or do I need another application
to do this for me, or?

98
00:06:22.260 --> 00:06:26.590
>> It's really one of
those things that depends.

99
00:06:26.590 --> 00:06:29.990
There are situations
where it's just provided

100
00:06:29.990 --> 00:06:32.680
as part of its core functioning on Java.

101
00:06:32.680 --> 00:06:38.840
Java has that built-in to it
as part of its foundation.

102
00:06:38.840 --> 00:06:42.330
And so it's a core thing,
it's provided by default.

103
00:06:42.330 --> 00:06:44.910

00:27:41.828 --> 00:27:45.750
because this product did
real time rendering.

482
00:27:45.750 --> 00:27:47.690
You could spin the stuff in real time,
and the lights and

483
00:27:47.690 --> 00:27:51.470
everything would change position
depending on what material you had,

484
00:27:51.470 --> 00:27:54.060
you owed each other,
push the sparkle or everything on it.

485
00:27:54.060 --> 00:27:55.270
It's really quite neat.

486
00:27:55.270 --> 00:27:56.210
As you can imagine, there's a lot

487
00:27:56.210 --> 00:27:58.950
of horsepower involved in
doing something like that.

488
00:27:58.950 --> 00:28:04.140
So what it did is it had in the background
there was another process that this

489
00:28:04.140 --> 00:28:09.640
application would spawn and
would do hidden line removal and

490
00:28:09.640 --> 00:28:14.580
do a real time lighting and
all that on it, it was this,

491
00:28:14.580 --> 00:28:18.890
so, it looked really cool but it required,
you know, a horsepower to do it.

492
00:28:18.890 --> 00:28:22.610
And, that horsepower came in
the form of extra memory and

493
00:28:22.610 --> 00:28:25.280
extra processor that was required.

494
00:28:25.280 --> 00:28:30.508
I remember, when I was working with that,
having a, a client call and say,

495
00:28:30.508 --> 00:28:37.080
this part is having just a ton
of problems with it because

496
00:28:37.080 --> 00:28:42.150
it keeps crashing and it keeps trying
to suck more memory on the system,

497
00:28:42.150 --> 00:28:48.240
way more than it should and it's like,
okay let's see what's going on.

498
00:28:48.240 --> 00:28:52.280
Indeed was when he looked
at his memory just alone,

499
00:28:52.280 --> 00:28:55.830
he had a quite a bit of memory on
his system, it was disappearing,

500
00:28:55.830 --> 00:29:02.110
a lot of it was disappearing, many more
than the host application was taking up.

501
00:29:02.110 --> 00:29:03.437
And what he was looking at,

502
00:29:03.437 --> 00:29:07.077
he was looking off the side another
application that happened to be one that

503
00:29:07.077 --> 00:29:10.840
the saw modeler spawned to do all
this stuff Mike it was talking about.

504
00:29:10.840 --> 00:29:12.500
It was going through
doing all of this stuff.

505
00:29:12.500 --> 00:29:16.020
As the model got more complex and
had more fasts and stuff like that on it,

506
00:29:16.020 --> 00:29:18.370
show up and
different materials start getting mixed,

507
00:29:18.370 --> 00:29:21.130
it was causing that
process to do more work.

508
00:29:21.130 --> 00:29:24.060
So it's sucking up more processor
because that needs that and

509
00:29:24.060 --> 00:29:26.080
it was taking up more memory
because it needs to do that.

510
00:29:26.080 --> 00:29:28.500
And it was creating
stuff on the hard drive.

511
00:29:28.500 --> 00:29:33.250
But if you looked at the software
that we had shipped out,

512
00:29:33.250 --> 00:29:38.760
that was where he said that if you
create a model at certain sizes,

513
00:29:38.760 --> 00:29:41.690
you're gonna have to start bumping up your
memory to certain levels, and we gave

514
00:29:41.690 --> 00:29:46.430
really strict recommendations and said
that hey, you need to at least have this.

515
00:29:46.430 --> 00:29:48.612
This guy was like oh I don't have
enough memory, just kill that process.

516
00:29:48.612 --> 00:29:53.130
Every time he did it,
it would just shut down that process.

517
00:29:53.130 --> 00:29:55.170
It would interfere with
that real time rendering.

518
00:29:55.170 --> 00:29:58.000
And what it would do is it would try
to respond and he'd kill it again.

519
00:29:58.000 --> 00:30:01.420
He did it enough times the application
would say something's going wrong here,

520
00:30:01.420 --> 00:30:03.060
and it would crash the whole thing.

521
00:30:03.060 --> 00:30:08.960
Hence his calls to me going you guys got
a nasty memory leak on your application,

522
00:30:08.960 --> 00:30:11.350
and I keep shutting this
down to get the memory back.

523
00:30:11.350 --> 00:30:14.495
And I look again 20 minutes later
it's sucking up all its memory again.

524
00:30:14.495 --> 00:30:16.450
>> [LAUGH]
>> Like how much memory do you have and

525
00:30:16.450 --> 00:30:16.990
blah, blah, blah.

526
00:30:16.990 --> 00:30:18.363
It was him doing it
>> [LAUGH]

527
00:30:18.363 --> 00:30:18.960
>> It was him doing it.

528
00:30:18.960 --> 00:30:23.770
He was doing it over and he was It
was basically going through there and

529
00:30:23.770 --> 00:30:25.800
doing it, and sabotaging himself.

530
00:30:25.800 --> 00:30:27.860
The application was doing
what it was supposed to.

531
00:30:27.860 --> 00:30:31.410
It didn't have a memory
leak in that situation.

532
00:30:31.410 --> 00:30:37.350
It was just him saying oh well he didn't
think that that was the way that it should

533
00:30:37.350 --> 00:30:37.880
operate.

534
00:30:37.880 --> 00:30:40.020
It looked out of the ordinary to to him.

535
00:30:40.020 --> 00:30:41.530
>> We should-
>> Wasn't an idiot by the way.

536
00:30:41.530 --> 00:30:43.500
He knew what, he was a a smart guy.

537
00:30:43.500 --> 00:30:47.580
He was a case of that he
didn't know what that did and

538
00:30:47.580 --> 00:30:49.080
he just did what he'd always done.

539
00:30:49.080 --> 00:30:50.480
That's taking up too much memory, kill it.

540
00:30:50.480 --> 00:30:52.480
I'm using this program over here and
i know what this is and

541
00:30:52.480 --> 00:30:53.980
I don't know what that is.

542
00:30:53.980 --> 00:30:55.320
I'm just gonna get rid of it.

543
00:30:55.320 --> 00:30:57.265
>> That's one of the good old PEBCAKs.

544
00:30:57.265 --> 00:30:59.740
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, I remember after I told him,

545
00:30:59.740 --> 00:31:01.440
he was like I feel really dumb.

546
00:31:01.440 --> 00:31:03.790
I'm like hey, it happens.

547
00:31:03.790 --> 00:31:05.965
>> Right. [LAUGH] >> I mean you're dumb,
but it happens.

548
00:31:05.965 --> 00:31:08.640
[LAUGH] No, he was a good guy.

549
00:31:08.640 --> 00:31:10.200
>> A lot great information.

550
00:31:10.200 --> 00:31:11.050
Good episode there Sean.

551
00:31:11.050 --> 00:31:12.830
But that's going to do it for this one.

552
00:31:12.830 --> 00:31:15.700
So signing off for ITProTV,
I'm Mike Roderick.

553
00:31:15.700 --> 00:31:16.640
>> And I'm Sean Oriyano.

554
00:31:16.640 --> 00:31:18.288
>> And we'll see you next time.

555
00:31:18.288 --> 00:31:18.788
[SOUND]

episodes.description: Penetration testing plays a valuable role in determining what one's security stance actually is. Viewers will hear discussions about when it is necessary to perform a penetration test, some of the involved steps, and how to decide areas for assessment.
episodes.title: Penetration Testing
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.366 --> 00:00:10.366
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.523 --> 00:00:15.481
Hello, and welcome to another episode
of ITProTV I'm your host Mike Roderick.

3
00:00:15.481 --> 00:00:18.083
With me today is Mr.
Sean Oriyano, how you doing Sean?

4
00:00:18.083 --> 00:00:20.000
>> I'm doing pretty good,
how are you doing today?

5
00:00:20.000 --> 00:00:21.090
>> I'm doing fantastic.

6
00:00:21.090 --> 00:00:24.470
Excited because we have more
CompTIA Advanced Security Practitioner

7
00:00:24.470 --> 00:00:28.350
coming your way and in this one, we're
going to be talking about pen testing or

8
00:00:28.350 --> 00:00:32.050
penetration testing, I guess I should
say the full name there the first time.

9
00:00:32.050 --> 00:00:36.580
But, this is something that we've
got to have in our bag of tools,

10
00:00:36.580 --> 00:00:39.500
when it comes to designing
a secure network, right?

11
00:00:39.500 --> 00:00:45.090
>> Yeah, absolutely, as it's such
a valuable part of determining

12
00:00:45.090 --> 00:00:47.600
what your security stance actually is.

13
00:00:47.600 --> 00:00:50.730
Because without it, yeah,
you can do audits and

14
00:00:50.730 --> 00:00:54.110
you can do vulnerability scanning and
stuff like that, but

15
00:00:54.110 --> 00:00:57.641
that's not really going up
to the level of pentesting.

16
00:00:57.641 --> 00:01:02.250
Pentesting is much more aggressive,
it's much more realistic.

17
00:01:02.250 --> 00:01:07.240
>> And it's something that's gonna give
you results that you can actually work on,

18
00:01:07.240 --> 00:01:12.620
that you can see that this is what's
happening in my system, this is what

19
00:01:12.620 --> 00:01:18.180
a black hat would see, and it's trying
to go in and get in and cause damage.

20
00:01:18.180 --> 00:01:20.110
So it's a really good way to do things.

21
00:01:20.110 --> 00:01:23.470
But it's not something that's
appropriate for every situation.

22
00:01:23.470 --> 00:01:27.720
It's something you gotta realize
that aside form the intention,

23
00:01:27.720 --> 00:01:32.360
the fact that I'm authorized by you, I
have your blessing as a client to do this,

24
00:01:32.360 --> 00:01:34.110
if I'm coming as a pen tester.

25
00:01:34.110 --> 00:01:36.400
That's the exact same tools and
techniques.

26
00:01:36.400 --> 00:01:40.413
So that translates to, if something
bad is gonna happen with black hats,

27
00:01:40.413 --> 00:01:43.143
something bad is gonna
happen when I'm doing it.

28
00:01:43.143 --> 00:01:45.989
So there's a possibility-
>> Doesn't matter whose doing it whether

29
00:01:45.989 --> 00:01:48.622
I'm meaning to be malicious or
I'm doing this for

30
00:01:48.622 --> 00:01:50.701
a good reason the results are the same.

31
00:01:50.701 --> 00:01:52.349
>> Yeah,exactly.

32
00:01:52.349 --> 00:01:56.400
>> Yep, so really pen-testing can
do a couple things for us, right?

33
00:01:56.400 --> 00:01:59.044
I mean it can show us where
we're still vulnerable.

34
00:01:59.044 --> 00:02:03.568
It can also be a way to verify all
the hard work that I put in to designing

35
00:02:03.568 --> 00:02:04.740
a secure system.

36
00:02:04.740 --> 00:02:06.530
And it gave me a way to
verify the results, or

37
00:02:06.530 --> 00:02:09.525
to say look I really did do
a good job securing this.

38
00:02:09.525 --> 00:02:12.380
>> Yeah, it's a sanity check really,
or trust but verify,

39
00:02:12.380 --> 00:02:13.990
if you wanna use that one.

40
00:02:13.990 --> 00:02:16.430
That's exactly what it is.

41
00:02:16.430 --> 00:02:22.360
Nothing's saying that as a pen
tester I have to find a problem.

42
00:02:23.380 --> 00:02:28.120
That's part of the thing, is that I've
done pen tests within the parameters

43
00:02:28.120 --> 00:02:31.370
that they've given me,
I haven't found any major issues.

44
00:02:32.430 --> 00:02:36.895
I've found maybe some medium level ones,
and some kind of like, hey FYI.

45
00:02:36.895 --> 00:02:42.585
But I didn't find anything that was really
major, those clients come back to me,

46
00:02:42.585 --> 00:02:45.560
and they're like you didn't find anything,
any big problems.

47
00:02:45.560 --> 00:02:49.190
I'm like, well,
I'm sure there's big problems,

48
00:02:49.190 --> 00:02:53.100
because I can see it's kind of peeking
out a bit and I kind of indicated that.

49
00:02:53.100 --> 00:02:57.210
But within the parameters you gave me,
I can't go after and

50
00:02:57.210 --> 00:03:02.410
strike against those,
because it wasn't authorized to do it.

51
00:03:02.410 --> 00:03:05.827
And so I'll usually have a discussion
with them before I get to that point,

52
00:03:05.827 --> 00:03:08.213
saying I think there was
an area of concern here, and

53
00:03:08.213 --> 00:03:10.561
I'll tell you why I think
it's an area of concern.

54
00:03:10.561 --> 00:03:13.100
Do you want me to do that?

55
00:03:13.100 --> 00:03:14.560
This is what could happen.

56
00:03:14.560 --> 00:03:18.870
Or do you want me to leave it off limits
and let, and just say, hey I found it.

57
00:03:18.870 --> 00:03:21.320
And you can pass it on your IT guys or
whomever.

58
00:03:22.390 --> 00:03:23.726
>> That's nice of you.

59
00:03:23.726 --> 00:03:27.530
I've found a buff where you might be
susceptible to a buffer overflow attack,

60
00:03:27.530 --> 00:03:30.810
but I didn't actually perform the attack
and bring your entire system down and

61
00:03:30.810 --> 00:03:32.430
shut your e-commerce system down.

62
00:03:32.430 --> 00:03:34.012
So that's a good thing, thank you, Sean.

63
00:03:34.012 --> 00:03:35.928
>> Try that with a black hat.

64
00:03:35.928 --> 00:03:37.297
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

65
00:03:37.297 --> 00:03:37.900
>> Yeah,

66
00:03:37.900 --> 00:03:43.340
that's a the thing that you've
got to realize when you do this.

67
00:03:43.340 --> 00:03:45.130
The dangers are the same.

68
00:03:45.130 --> 00:03:49.523
What might actually kind of pull you away
from having the same level of danger is

69
00:03:49.523 --> 00:03:54.250
what you were talking about Mike,

70
00:03:54.250 --> 00:03:57.700
is that, hey, thanks for
letting us know, but not doing it.

71
00:03:57.700 --> 00:03:59.468
That's one of the benefits
you get with a pen tester.

72
00:03:59.468 --> 00:04:05.430
If I'm pen testing for you and I find
a problem, if I think it's bad enough,

73
00:04:05.430 --> 00:04:07.900
I'm going to use my judgment to say,
I know this is an issue,

74
00:04:07.900 --> 00:04:10.630
I see all the hallmarks and
fingerprints all over this.

75
00:04:10.630 --> 00:04:11.930
Before I do anything,

76
00:04:11.930 --> 00:04:16.940
maybe I want to talk to the client to say,
do you want me to really do this?

77
00:04:16.940 --> 00:04:20.320
Because I can cause significant
amount of damage doing this.

78
00:04:20.320 --> 00:04:25.050
And so, they can decide yeah okay,
we want to see how bad it can be cuz

79
00:04:25.050 --> 00:04:27.740
we want to test maybe our
incident response as well.

80
00:04:27.740 --> 00:04:31.438
If they're fine with that, then, okay.

81
00:04:31.438 --> 00:04:34.512
>> Sean's eyes light up and
he starts doing this with his hands and

82
00:04:34.512 --> 00:04:35.623
this maniacal laugh.

83
00:04:35.623 --> 00:04:36.285
>> Excellent.

84
00:04:36.285 --> 00:04:40.508
>> Yeah [LAUGH]
>> See that's where I come in,

85
00:04:40.508 --> 00:04:42.866
I get the cat out,
let's take this to the next level.

86
00:04:42.866 --> 00:04:49.409
[LAUGH] So, but it is something that yeah
you got to realize it can happen, but

87
00:04:49.409 --> 00:04:54.418
you also, on that same token,
if I'm doing something and

88
00:04:54.418 --> 00:05:00.610
stuff starts to negatively impact you,
you've got me on the hotline.

89
00:05:00.610 --> 00:05:04.490
You can call me up, yeah,
stop whatever you're doing.

90
00:05:04.490 --> 00:05:10.125
What you're doing, why justified,
they'll say something that you're

91
00:05:10.125 --> 00:05:15.314
doing is having much more far-reaching
effects than we would like,

92
00:05:15.314 --> 00:05:18.274
so you need to stop what you're doing.

93
00:05:18.274 --> 00:05:23.200
>> Exactly, so now when we look at pen
testing, there's different what we

94
00:05:23.200 --> 00:05:28.320
call box methods that we can use,
and so how do we break those down?

95
00:05:28.320 --> 00:05:31.130
>> Yeah, there's really three types

96
00:05:31.130 --> 00:05:36.460
of boxes that you have that
you can put your test within.

97
00:05:36.460 --> 00:05:39.787
And you don't know what box you're in
until you actually observe it, okay.

98
00:05:39.787 --> 00:05:42.050
>> [LAUGH]
>> Schroedinger's Cat.

99
00:05:42.050 --> 00:05:43.268
[CROSSTALK] That's right.

100
00:05:43.268 --> 00:05:44.916
It's Friday and I'm pulling that stuff.

101
00:05:44.916 --> 00:05:46.008
>> [LAUGH]
>> You miss it?

102
00:05:46.008 --> 00:05:46.670
Too bad.

103
00:05:46.670 --> 00:05:50.188
[LAUGH]
>> I'm still gonna get you that shirt that

104
00:05:50.188 --> 00:05:53.416
has the Schroedinger's cat wanted dead and
alive.

105
00:05:53.416 --> 00:05:55.133
>> [LAUGH] Yeah.

106
00:05:55.133 --> 00:06:00.158
I know of, what we got black box,

107
00:06:00.158 --> 00:06:03.577
white box, gray box.

108
00:06:03.577 --> 00:06:04.099
Tell us about those guys.

109
00:06:04.099 --> 00:06:08.244
>> Those are the three big
ones you're gonna run into.

110
00:06:08.244 --> 00:06:12.178
To be fair there's other forms of tests
you can do that don't fit the category of

111
00:06:12.178 --> 00:06:14.305
one of these traditional box categories.

112
00:06:14.305 --> 00:06:18.494
And feel free to explore
those if you want.

113
00:06:18.494 --> 00:06:24.264
One of the reasons why I wouldn't discuss
them in a place like this, is because

114
00:06:24.264 --> 00:06:29.511
there's still a lot of disagreement,
not like nasty disagreements,

115
00:06:29.511 --> 00:06:34.496
but there's disagreements on
are those actual separate tests, or

116
00:06:34.496 --> 00:06:39.216
are those just a variation on
a theme with the black, white, and

117
00:06:39.216 --> 00:06:42.090
the gray, you know, so.

118
00:06:42.090 --> 00:06:43.010
Just keep that in mind,

119
00:06:43.010 --> 00:06:47.660
if you're seeing it go well wait a minute,
there's a big long list of tests here.

120
00:06:47.660 --> 00:06:50.780
I see, I've searched on the Internet and
found them.

121
00:06:50.780 --> 00:06:55.280
Not saying you're wrong, I'm just saying
that that's another way of looking at it.

122
00:06:55.280 --> 00:06:59.440
But the three we've got when we look at
those, we have a black box, which means,

123
00:06:59.440 --> 00:07:04.070
you don't have really information or
is extremely limited,

124
00:07:04.070 --> 00:07:10.530
meaning that they can give you parameters
on striking out on a target to strike.

125
00:07:10.530 --> 00:07:14.462
Saying okay, well this is the company,
and this is our IP address and that's it.

126
00:07:14.462 --> 00:07:16.600
That's all you're getting.

127
00:07:16.600 --> 00:07:19.930
And then they can go all the way to
the other extreme with the white box,

128
00:07:19.930 --> 00:07:22.680
it's where you have full knowledge and
full disclosure.

129
00:07:22.680 --> 00:07:26.770
Both of those have their time and place.

130
00:07:26.770 --> 00:07:31.440
A black box is going to simulate
exactly what an attacker would see,

131
00:07:31.440 --> 00:07:34.080
whereas a white box is going to be

132
00:07:34.080 --> 00:07:37.910
internally you doing a sanity check
on whatever it is you implemented.

133
00:07:37.910 --> 00:07:42.180
Now, that still leaves us with one
right there which is the grey box,

134
00:07:42.180 --> 00:07:45.880
which, you figure just by the name,
it's in between the two.

135
00:07:45.880 --> 00:07:51.910
So, it must mean that we have
partial knowledge, but not full.

136
00:07:51.910 --> 00:07:53.216
What the heck would that do?

137
00:07:53.216 --> 00:07:58.254
It seems like if you've got partial
knowledge, isn't that a bad thing?

138
00:07:58.254 --> 00:08:02.280
Isn't that something that's tainting what
you're gonna go in either direction,

139
00:08:02.280 --> 00:08:05.408
cuz you're not keeping anything from it,
and you're not, so.

140
00:08:05.408 --> 00:08:09.772
You're not doing what a black hat would do
but you're not going all the way to white

141
00:08:09.772 --> 00:08:13.220
hat and giving me everything,
so why would I do that?

142
00:08:13.220 --> 00:08:19.120
Well, we could go down many different
roads with why you do that,

143
00:08:19.120 --> 00:08:24.860
but one of the biggest ones is that if,
let's say I'm doing a black box test,

144
00:08:24.860 --> 00:08:28.140
it's more than likely gonna
happen in this situation.

145
00:08:28.140 --> 00:08:29.780
If you do a pure black box test,

146
00:08:29.780 --> 00:08:33.070
the kind of assumption is that you're
gonna find out everything, and

147
00:08:33.070 --> 00:08:37.340
they're gonna give you an ultimate goal to
accomplish, or parameters to stay within.

episodes.description: There are a lot of different risks that can harm the integrity of a collection of data, which include data corruption, data deletion, and data theft. Risk management involves identifying risks and then finding ways to mitigate those risks to prevent possible damage. Viewers will hear about the process of risk management and assessing risks in a business setting.

Those would be very,

00:26:27.850 --> 00:26:33.340
unique and able to really have
its standing is its customers.

443
00:26:33.340 --> 00:26:36.825
People are dumping money and
keeping it there because the bank is doing

444
00:26:36.825 --> 00:26:40.485
investments and all this other stuff
with it, and they can boast that they

445
00:26:40.485 --> 00:26:44.232
have these large customers and this
much in assets to attract more people.

446
00:26:44.232 --> 00:26:47.854
Take that uniqueness away,
what do you have?

447
00:26:47.854 --> 00:26:49.282
You don't have that.

448
00:26:49.282 --> 00:26:53.982
Same thing with companies who have product
portfolios, if your someone like Microsoft

449
00:26:53.982 --> 00:26:57.928
and I take away all your data on your
whole product portfolio what are you?

450
00:26:57.928 --> 00:27:00.525
You're just a big software company.

451
00:27:00.525 --> 00:27:06.935
So that's something that that data
is very much a big deal that you

452
00:27:06.935 --> 00:27:12.645
have to keep that safe, if you don't,
there's going to be a big problem.

453
00:27:12.645 --> 00:27:15.995
>> All right well Sean a lot
of great information there on

454
00:27:15.995 --> 00:27:19.900
getting our feet wet into risk management.

455
00:27:19.900 --> 00:27:23.000
Anything else we want to toss in here,
before we call this one a wrap.

456
00:27:23.000 --> 00:27:25.630
>> I think we're doing
pretty good on that.

457
00:27:25.630 --> 00:27:26.820
>> All right, I give up.

458
00:27:26.820 --> 00:27:28.700
Hope you guys enjoy watching this one.

459
00:27:28.700 --> 00:27:31.770
Sign off for ITProTV, I am Mike Rodrick,
>> I am Sean Oriyano

460
00:27:31.770 --> 00:27:33.112
>> And we'll see you next time.

461
00:27:33.112 --> 00:27:38.950
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In the process of risk assessment, one should know what assets they are protecting from risk. Viewers will hear about the different steps involved in the risk assessment process including asset identification, information classification, risk assessment, risk analysis, implementing controls, and continuous monitoring.
episodes.title: Risk Assessment Process
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.946 --> 00:00:10.807
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10.807 --> 00:00:13.020
Hello, and
welcome to another episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:13.020 --> 00:00:14.760
I'm your host Mike Rodrick.

4
00:00:14.760 --> 00:00:16.053
With me today is Mr. Sean Oriyano.

5
00:00:16.053 --> 00:00:17.440
How you doing Sean?

6
00:00:17.440 --> 00:00:18.040
>> I'm doing pretty good.

7
00:00:18.040 --> 00:00:19.730
How you doing?
>> I'm doing great,

8
00:00:19.730 --> 00:00:23.230
because we're here doing our CompTIA
Advanced Security Practitioners Series.

9
00:00:23.230 --> 00:00:26.750
And in this episode we're gonna
continue on with risk management.

10
00:00:26.750 --> 00:00:30.560
Now we're gonna break down physically
the risk assessment process,

11
00:00:30.560 --> 00:00:33.050
cuz there definitely is a procedure or

12
00:00:33.050 --> 00:00:36.430
process that we need to follow
when we're doing risk analysis.

13
00:00:36.430 --> 00:00:40.610
>> Yeah, it's not something that
you just kind of throw stuff at and

14
00:00:40.610 --> 00:00:42.380
see what sticks.

15
00:00:42.380 --> 00:00:46.419
At this level, you're starting
to break it down into individual

16
00:00:48.110 --> 00:00:51.830
steps in overall process to make
sure stuff is getting done and

17
00:00:51.830 --> 00:00:56.140
stuff is getting addressed the way
it's supposed to rather than just hey,

18
00:00:56.140 --> 00:00:59.240
throw some stuff here and
there and hope it works.

19
00:00:59.240 --> 00:01:00.910
We have the steps we have to follow.

20
00:01:00.910 --> 00:01:05.580
And heck, we maybe mandated that we have
to follow that either by the higher ups or

21
00:01:05.580 --> 00:01:07.940
by legal regulations or both.

22
00:01:07.940 --> 00:01:10.860
And there could be other stuff
in there that's driving this.

23
00:01:10.860 --> 00:01:14.730
So we have to make sure that this is
being done and being done consistently,

24
00:01:14.730 --> 00:01:19.620
reliably and even verifiably we
can do that each and every time.

25
00:01:19.620 --> 00:01:20.455
>> There we go.

26
00:01:20.455 --> 00:01:24.720
Like governmental regulation when it comes
to like power and water treatment and

27
00:01:24.720 --> 00:01:25.450
things like that.

28
00:01:25.450 --> 00:01:29.620
There's industry regulations when it
comes to banking and stuff like that.

29
00:01:29.620 --> 00:01:32.753
And then, of course, there's my own
company might have its own regulations and

30
00:01:32.753 --> 00:01:35.070
say, hey we've gotta do this
every quarter or every year.

31
00:01:35.070 --> 00:01:37.940
So, could come from many different angles.

32
00:01:37.940 --> 00:01:40.640
But there is a basic process, right?

33
00:01:40.640 --> 00:01:45.900
And that first step, Sean, is identifying
the risks that, or the assets, I'm sorry.

34
00:01:45.900 --> 00:01:47.920
We gotta figure out what
it is we need to protect.

35
00:01:47.920 --> 00:01:49.770
>> Yeah, that's the foundation.

36
00:01:49.770 --> 00:01:53.090
If you don't know what you're protecting,
then you need to stop,

37
00:01:53.090 --> 00:01:58.020
you need to figure out what you're doing,
and go back to the drawing board, and say,

38
00:01:58.020 --> 00:01:59.750
what is it I'm trying
to build a wall around?

39
00:01:59.750 --> 00:02:00.940
That's just not gonna help.

40
00:02:00.940 --> 00:02:02.478
>> If you don't know what
you're trying to protect,

41
00:02:02.478 --> 00:02:03.598
it's very difficult to protect it.

42
00:02:03.598 --> 00:02:07.140
>> Yeah, you just can't have that.

43
00:02:07.140 --> 00:02:12.570
So you gotta know where or
what you are trying to protect.

44
00:02:12.570 --> 00:02:16.580
And what you're trying to protect it from,
would be even the next part of it.

45
00:02:16.580 --> 00:02:18.540
Without knowing what
you're trying to protect,

46
00:02:18.540 --> 00:02:20.960
what are you going to position
your defenses around?

47
00:02:20.960 --> 00:02:24.570
Be like building the Wall of China,
and figure it out?

48
00:02:24.570 --> 00:02:28.202
Well, it's not China i'm protecting,
building it around some other,

49
00:02:28.202 --> 00:02:28.970
like Germany?

50
00:02:28.970 --> 00:02:31.225
Well, they had a wall, so
don't worry about that.

51
00:02:31.225 --> 00:02:33.851
>> [LAUGH]
>> Figuring out you're building a wall

52
00:02:33.851 --> 00:02:38.118
ain't gonna make it work unless you
know what it is you're trying to protect

53
00:02:38.118 --> 00:02:40.530
as well as what you're trying to keep out.

54
00:02:40.530 --> 00:02:42.570
>> Yeah.
So asset identification then.

55
00:02:42.570 --> 00:02:44.380
Phase 1 of our risk management.

56
00:02:44.380 --> 00:02:48.040
And that's going to include things
that you probably will think of

57
00:02:48.040 --> 00:02:50.710
as well as some things that
we might not think of right?

58
00:02:50.710 --> 00:02:56.850
>> Yes and this is why asset
identification can take quite a while.

59
00:02:56.850 --> 00:03:02.190
In fact, if you really,
really get into the brass tacks and

60
00:03:02.190 --> 00:03:06.910
fine details with this, there's just
tremendous amount of ways to figure out

61
00:03:06.910 --> 00:03:10.750
what type of asset you're trying to
protect and how valuable they are.

62
00:03:10.750 --> 00:03:15.850
Because it's not just a question of just
that we have our asset sitting here.

63
00:03:15.850 --> 00:03:19.440
Some of those assets are gonna
just by their very nature be more

64
00:03:19.440 --> 00:03:20.170
important than others.

65
00:03:20.170 --> 00:03:21.980
They're not all created equal.

66
00:03:21.980 --> 00:03:25.910
So you need to figure that out by
doing things like what they call

67
00:03:25.910 --> 00:03:28.090
quantitative and qualitative analysis.

68
00:03:28.090 --> 00:03:33.640
Which is where you use numeric values or

69
00:03:33.640 --> 00:03:37.190
grades on stuff,
as well as opinions on the other side.

70
00:03:37.190 --> 00:03:41.710
To figure out from subject matter experts
in both cases, to figure out how valuable

71
00:03:41.710 --> 00:03:47.910
each asset is and what would happen if you
lost said asset in the scheme of things.

72
00:03:47.910 --> 00:03:52.470
So that's a very, very important thing to
get and that's a very important thing to

73
00:03:52.470 --> 00:03:56.480
spend some good serious time on,
figure out all those things.

74
00:03:56.480 --> 00:03:59.630
And you are not going to do this on your
own, that's kind of what you're getting to

75
00:03:59.630 --> 00:04:02.200
here, is that,
maybe things you don't expect.

76
00:04:03.390 --> 00:04:04.390
You're not going to know it all.

77
00:04:04.390 --> 00:04:06.740
I don't care how good
you are as a CASP and

78
00:04:06.740 --> 00:04:10.140
how ready you are to go up
the food chain even further.

79
00:04:10.140 --> 00:04:11.430
You're not going to know it all.

80
00:04:11.430 --> 00:04:17.241
You need to solicit the help of
people in other departments or

81
00:04:17.241 --> 00:04:21.470
more close to the action in a lot of these
cases, to see what types of things are out

82
00:04:21.470 --> 00:04:25.630
there so you can make sure you're
adequately covering everything.

83
00:04:25.630 --> 00:04:29.410
And obviously it's your technology,
it's your facilities,

84
00:04:29.410 --> 00:04:31.430
it's preserving your business processes.

85
00:04:31.430 --> 00:04:32.930
That would be an asset.

86
00:04:32.930 --> 00:04:35.240
And then it's even people.

87
00:04:35.240 --> 00:04:39.650
People are thrown into that mix and people
are one of the things that are right

88
00:04:39.650 --> 00:04:42.240
on the top of the list of things
that you need to protect.

89
00:04:42.240 --> 00:04:46.108
I mean there's really, as much as
some people might not like to think,

90
00:04:46.108 --> 00:04:49.144
there's nothing above people
in the scheme of things.

91
00:04:49.144 --> 00:04:55.500
You look at it, when you're talking
about people and assets to protect.

92
00:04:56.820 --> 00:04:59.800
Just think about if
a disaster were to happen,

93
00:04:59.800 --> 00:05:02.090
a fire started burning in the building,
what are you gonna do?

94
00:05:02.090 --> 00:05:03.630
Are you gonna your printer or

95
00:05:03.630 --> 00:05:07.770
your potted plant, or are you gonna start
getting people out of the building?

96
00:05:07.770 --> 00:05:10.600
That's a question that if you
can't answer it the right way,

97
00:05:10.600 --> 00:05:15.550
you really need to stop what you're doing
and figure out, where's your medication.

98
00:05:15.550 --> 00:05:19.420
[LAUGH] In all seriousness,
you need to figure out

99
00:05:19.420 --> 00:05:24.070
if people aren't at the top of your list,
well then,

100
00:05:24.070 --> 00:05:27.090
why aren't they at the top of your list,
and how are you gonna put them there?

101
00:05:27.090 --> 00:05:28.770
>> And then some of your people might be,

102
00:05:28.770 --> 00:05:32.320
not that any of your people are
unimportant, but you've got key people.

103
00:05:32.320 --> 00:05:36.347
Maybe you've got a software project
development project that's going on.

104
00:05:36.347 --> 00:05:39.850
And then you got one guy that's kind
of masterminding the whole application.

105
00:05:39.850 --> 00:05:46.280
You lose that person because of health
issues or he quits or something like that,

106
00:05:46.280 --> 00:05:51.670
that could throw that whole project into
the circular or the round can down there.

107
00:05:51.670 --> 00:05:54.970
And that's something that you gotta
think about, that you might not have.

108
00:05:54.970 --> 00:05:58.290
When you first think about risk analysis,
we think about things like fires and

109
00:05:58.290 --> 00:06:01.810
tornadoes and hurricanes and floods and
bad guys trying to steal our data.

110
00:06:01.810 --> 00:06:05.600
Didn't think about if this person quits,
that could ruin everything.

111
00:06:05.600 --> 00:06:08.450
>> You know you bring up a very
good point here with that.

112
00:06:08.450 --> 00:06:14.693
Is when you get to a large
enterprise level organizations.

113
00:06:14.693 --> 00:06:19.320
And really any organization like you said,
everyone's important.

114
00:06:19.320 --> 00:06:22.410
There's just different shades of
it in terms of when you look at

115
00:06:22.410 --> 00:06:24.200
keeping the business going.

116
00:06:24.200 --> 00:06:26.770
One of the things I know
with enterprise companies.

117
00:06:26.770 --> 00:06:30.480
I can tell you from working
at several of them, or

118
00:06:30.480 --> 00:06:33.510
interacting with several of them I
guess is a better way to put it.

119
00:06:33.510 --> 00:06:38.990
That, well heck,
I can use the one I worked with years ago.

120
00:06:38.990 --> 00:06:42.740
The executive staff and
the board and all those things,

121
00:06:42.740 --> 00:06:46.440
they actually had a document that
said who could travel with who.

122
00:06:46.440 --> 00:06:52.350
That was kinda the, one of the things
where this led to was that they

123
00:06:52.350 --> 00:06:57.510
determined who were key personnel
that need to be kept in place.

124
00:06:57.510 --> 00:07:02.270
If the company somehow, if there was
a disaster or something, they said they

125
00:07:02.270 --> 00:07:06.090
didn't want to shove all the key staff on
one plane and have that plane go down.

126
00:07:06.090 --> 00:07:09.280
So what they would do is say okay,
this person travel with this person but

127
00:07:09.280 --> 00:07:10.970
this person can't travel with this person.

128
00:07:10.970 --> 00:07:12.730
It was very clear.

129
00:07:12.730 --> 00:07:15.700
That certain combinations of
people could not travel together.

130
00:07:15.700 --> 00:07:20.080
Some people could not travel with anybody
else because if that person was lost, it

131
00:07:20.080 --> 00:07:26.170
would need the other people to be able to
fill that void if something had happened.

132
00:07:26.170 --> 00:07:30.200
And so that came out of who's who and
who's got what in their head,

133
00:07:30.200 --> 00:07:34.450
who's got certain business processes
stuff locked away in their gray matter.

134
00:07:35.470 --> 00:07:39.472
And we don't want to lose more than one
person or certain combinations of people,

135
00:07:39.472 --> 00:07:42.146
cuz that would be devastating,
we'll just avoid it.

136
00:07:42.146 --> 00:07:46.418
Once identified we'll put the chart out
saying when we're making reservations

137
00:07:46.418 --> 00:07:50.496
don't put these people in the same plane,
don't put them in the same hotel,

138
00:07:50.496 --> 00:07:51.560
just in case.

139
00:07:51.560 --> 00:07:52.562
>> Wow.

140
00:07:52.562 --> 00:07:54.850
That kind of leads right
into our next one,

141
00:07:54.850 --> 00:07:59.051
we go through our asset identification
where we're defining all our things we

142
00:07:59.051 --> 00:08:02.570
have to protect that are important
to our business information.

143
00:08:02.570 --> 00:08:06.470
We've said that data and information
is a very important part of that.

144
00:08:06.470 --> 00:08:11.120
But kind of like we said with people,
not all data is equal as well, right?

145
00:08:11.120 --> 00:08:12.272
>> Yeah, absolutely not.

146
00:08:12.272 --> 00:08:17.890
There's just an endless sea of information
that can stream out of any organization.

147
00:08:17.890 --> 00:08:19.370
And in fact, I think a statistic, well,

148
00:08:19.370 --> 00:08:23.480
it used to be that any company
you talked about the amount

149
00:08:23.480 --> 00:08:28.220
of data that they had would double in
size about every 18 months, more or less.

150
00:08:28.220 --> 00:08:31.208
That's probably been
accelerated a bit more.

151
00:08:31.208 --> 00:08:33.311
And who knows,
maybe it's less in some cases,

152
00:08:33.311 --> 00:08:35.108
depending on how active the company is.

153
00:08:35.108 --> 00:08:39.876
But you tend to say at 18 months is
still more or less accepted as kind of

154
00:08:39.876 --> 00:08:43.701
the line where you expect to
see your data double in size.

155
00:08:43.701 --> 00:08:47.513
But that doesn't mean just because your
data doubles in size that everything all

156
00:08:47.513 --> 00:08:49.608
of a sudden is magically really important.

157
00:08:49.608 --> 00:08:54.590
Data, information, whatever doubles
in size, even at your home.

158
00:08:54.590 --> 00:08:59.709
You look at the stuff that you have now,
receipts, and for things you may be

159
00:08:59.709 --> 00:09:05.168
doing to take off your taxes or your
bills, or what have you, all those things.

160
00:09:05.168 --> 00:09:10.454
Those just double, and every 18 months
you get more and more of those.

161
00:09:10.454 --> 00:09:13.486
Over that period of time,
you will double it in size on average, or

162
00:09:13.486 --> 00:09:15.011
do something pretty close to it.

163
00:09:15.011 --> 00:09:18.100
Does it mean that every little
receipt that you have is handy?

164
00:09:18.100 --> 00:09:23.169
No, if you're going through McDonald's,
or some drive in, or you're

165
00:09:23.169 --> 00:09:29.076
buying something at the grocery store,
that's not really sensitive information.

166
00:09:29.076 --> 00:09:30.028
I don't know what you're buying.

167
00:09:30.028 --> 00:09:32.350
But who knows?

168
00:09:32.350 --> 00:09:35.215
It's got secret sauce, man,
that's why I got to keep it secret.

169
00:09:35.215 --> 00:09:36.747
>> That's right.

170
00:09:36.747 --> 00:09:40.394
[LAUGHING].
>> But you don't know that everything

171
00:09:40.394 --> 00:09:44.480
in there's gonna be kept the same way.

172
00:09:44.480 --> 00:09:46.072
Your receipts from,
like I said, your fast food,

173
00:09:46.072 --> 00:09:47.960
your grocery are probably
not the big deal.

174
00:09:47.960 --> 00:09:49.756
But when you go and

175
00:09:49.756 --> 00:09:54.990
you look at stuff like your tax forms
you get at the beginning of the year,

176
00:09:54.990 --> 00:09:59.900
stuff like that, with your Social and
then medical records and all that.

177
00:09:59.900 --> 00:10:01.440
That's a lot more sensitive.

178
00:10:01.440 --> 00:10:05.580
So we see, just in the household we see
a difference in the types of information.

179
00:10:05.580 --> 00:10:11.348
Same thing with a business, you can have
stuff generated in the company picnic and

180
00:10:11.348 --> 00:10:15.706
stuff on, hey,
something new's coming out, or whatever.

181
00:10:15.706 --> 00:10:17.709
Up to emails and communications and

182
00:10:17.709 --> 00:10:21.582
data that contain very personal
information about your customers,

183
00:10:21.582 --> 00:10:25.670
stuff about business operations,
proprietary product information.

184
00:10:25.670 --> 00:10:30.735
And then you have stuff that would
be considered trade secrets that

185
00:10:30.735 --> 00:10:37.365
no one else can have because it would take
your advantage away, those type of things.

186
00:10:37.365 --> 00:10:39.385
You can keep going on and on and on.

187
00:10:39.385 --> 00:10:43.695
You have to figure out what those
assets are in each one of those things.

188
00:10:43.695 --> 00:10:47.645
Once you do it, now let's start figuring
out what's more valuable than others.

189
00:10:47.645 --> 00:10:49.746
Because some of those things you're gonna
put a lot more weight on than other stuff.

190
00:10:49.746 --> 00:10:52.161
It's like, you just wad it up in
a ball and throw it in the trash.

191
00:10:52.161 --> 00:10:58.081
I don't care if someone sees that we had,
the cafeteria was serving ribs today.

192
00:10:58.081 --> 00:10:59.690
I don't care.

193
00:10:59.690 --> 00:11:02.450
>> And that's really what, when it
comes to information classification,

194
00:11:02.450 --> 00:11:05.930
I guess, is the big part of it
because we can't just say data.

195
00:11:05.930 --> 00:11:08.450
Data has certain risks associated with it.

196
00:11:08.450 --> 00:11:11.276
We talked about like corruption or
deletion or theft.

197
00:11:11.276 --> 00:11:15.750
But I'm not gonna apply the same
mitigation techniques to all

198
00:11:15.750 --> 00:11:19.330
my data because some data is
more valuable than others.

199
00:11:19.330 --> 00:11:21.630
And so that's why we have
that classification is so

200
00:11:21.630 --> 00:11:25.560
we can figure out, all right, this data
we got to back it up four times a day.

201
00:11:25.560 --> 00:11:27.090
We got to keep a copy off site.

202
00:11:27.090 --> 00:11:28.580
We've got to do this and that.

203
00:11:28.580 --> 00:11:31.990
Whereas this other data,

00:23:31.528 --> 00:23:34.778
And those actions can be,
for example you can accept,

429
00:23:34.778 --> 00:23:38.181
you can just find with the risk
of list and say it's fine.

430
00:23:38.181 --> 00:23:39.928
I'm accepting it the way it is.

431
00:23:39.928 --> 00:23:44.203
There's nothing really here for
me to change.

432
00:23:44.203 --> 00:23:47.008
Okay?
If that's the case you can sign off on it

433
00:23:47.008 --> 00:23:48.943
and say we're leaving it as is.

434
00:23:48.943 --> 00:23:54.223
That's perfectly, no pun intended,
perfectly acceptable to do because

435
00:23:54.223 --> 00:23:59.352
you found out that there's really
not much variation or any variation.

436
00:23:59.352 --> 00:24:02.302
That's going to cause you to
not really want to do anything.

437
00:24:02.302 --> 00:24:04.760
So, leave it the way it is.

438
00:24:04.760 --> 00:24:06.020
Then you can mitigate it.

439
00:24:06.020 --> 00:24:10.330
Mitigate it means that you've decided that
that's not in line with your goals so

440
00:24:10.330 --> 00:24:13.850
you want to lower it to something
that's more acceptable to you.

441
00:24:13.850 --> 00:24:20.060
Then you can also do a transference which
is where you give it to a third party.

442
00:24:20.060 --> 00:24:22.740
That means insurance for example,

443
00:24:22.740 --> 00:24:25.670
you purchase insurance to cover that and
then one

444
00:24:25.670 --> 00:24:29.480
of the one you don't want to see is you
don't wanna see a denial type situation.

445
00:24:29.480 --> 00:24:34.710
Denial means that someone is just,
saying somewhere, no,

446
00:24:34.710 --> 00:24:36.570
this doesn't exist the way it is.

447
00:24:36.570 --> 00:24:40.706
They're kind of just putting their
fingers in their ears and ignoring you.

448
00:24:40.706 --> 00:24:43.240
>> [LAUGH]
>> That's incredibly bad if they're doing

449
00:24:43.240 --> 00:24:46.800
that because they're not even addressing,
or

450
00:24:46.800 --> 00:24:50.350
not even acknowledging the existence
of whatever it is you brought to them.

451
00:24:50.350 --> 00:24:53.880
If that's the case, you could have
a bad situation down the road.

452
00:24:53.880 --> 00:24:55.650
Not always, but you very well could.

453
00:24:55.650 --> 00:24:58.700
You're going to want to get
documentation and in any of these cases,

454
00:24:58.700 --> 00:25:03.250
especially that one to make sure that
is understood that this is brought to

455
00:25:03.250 --> 00:25:09.030
attention, this wasn't addressed, but
was definitely brought to attention.

456
00:25:09.030 --> 00:25:12.870
So you need to figure which one of
those actions you're gonna take.

457
00:25:12.870 --> 00:25:15.700
Now if its something like transference or

458
00:25:15.700 --> 00:25:19.870
mitigation, then you're gonna figure out
what controls are you gonna be required

459
00:25:19.870 --> 00:25:22.690
to bring that in to compliance
with what you need.

460
00:25:22.690 --> 00:25:24.570
If you're gonna transfer someone else,

461
00:25:24.570 --> 00:25:27.710
what level of insurance are you
gonna need if that's an option?

462
00:25:27.710 --> 00:25:33.410
If you have any situation where you can
do just do plain mitigation, well, then,

463
00:25:33.410 --> 00:25:37.350
what was your target goal and where are
you in relation to your target goal, and

464
00:25:37.350 --> 00:25:41.940
what can you do given all
the cost measures and budget?

465
00:25:41.940 --> 00:25:45.100
What can you do to bring
it into compliance and

466
00:25:45.100 --> 00:25:48.860
still stay within budget and
still stay on point with this.

467
00:25:48.860 --> 00:25:52.250
So the controls aren't just as simple as,
oh well, that's the problem,

468
00:25:52.250 --> 00:25:54.020
just start bolting some stuff in place.

469
00:25:54.020 --> 00:25:55.210
Absolutely not.

470
00:25:55.210 --> 00:25:57.490
It's much more than that.

471
00:25:57.490 --> 00:25:59.960
>> And then we've got to make
sure that we stay on top of it.

472
00:25:59.960 --> 00:26:01.870
Like you said earlier, things change.

473
00:26:01.870 --> 00:26:06.050
So we can't just do a risk analysis and
risk assessment once and

474
00:26:06.050 --> 00:26:06.830
forget about it, right?

475
00:26:06.830 --> 00:26:09.555
We've got to continuously monitor?

476
00:26:09.555 --> 00:26:14.444
>> Yeah, don't just assume this
is a fire and forget type thing,

477
00:26:14.444 --> 00:26:18.280
where you put the stuff out there and
it works.

478
00:26:18.280 --> 00:26:21.790
No, you have to have
continuous monitoring, and

479
00:26:21.790 --> 00:26:23.300
continuous monitoring is just that.

480
00:26:23.300 --> 00:26:24.620
It means that you're keeping an eye on it,

481
00:26:24.620 --> 00:26:27.940
making sure those things are working
the way they're supposed to.

482
00:26:27.940 --> 00:26:29.030
If they're not,

483
00:26:29.030 --> 00:26:33.750
then you'll take corrective actions
to bring them into compliance.

484
00:26:33.750 --> 00:26:37.930
That's gonna happen sometimes, that
something's not going to go as planned so

485
00:26:37.930 --> 00:26:42.590
now you kinda gotta get in there and
tweak it to make sure it does.

486
00:26:42.590 --> 00:26:44.610
And hopefully it's the case
of doing some adjustment.

487
00:26:44.610 --> 00:26:48.476
Sometimes when they implemented things,
they found out they don't work as planned.

488
00:26:48.476 --> 00:26:51.330
I know it's surprising.

489
00:26:51.330 --> 00:26:52.860
Stuff doesn't go as planned, so

490
00:26:52.860 --> 00:26:58.820
what you have to do is make some
adjustments to figure out what you can do.

491
00:26:58.820 --> 00:27:02.970
If not, maybe you'll have
to tear it out and redo it.

492
00:27:02.970 --> 00:27:04.850
That does happen unfortunately.

493
00:27:05.980 --> 00:27:08.420
You need to have that, but

494
00:27:08.420 --> 00:27:11.450
you're not going to know it unless
you're just continuously monitoring.

495
00:27:11.450 --> 00:27:16.408
It's also important to note that
continuous monitoring is a requirement in

496
00:27:16.408 --> 00:27:20.730
most cases, you just can't put
a plan in place and not monitor it.

497
00:27:20.730 --> 00:27:23.840
Because you could have
an outside agency that says,

498
00:27:23.840 --> 00:27:26.980
you put the stuff in place that's great,
when's the last time you verified it?

499
00:27:28.110 --> 00:27:31.040
About three years ago, that's good, right?

500
00:27:31.040 --> 00:27:33.650
No, probably not.

501
00:27:33.650 --> 00:27:35.030
>> Just a little while ago.

502
00:27:35.030 --> 00:27:36.705
>> Yeah,
it's not that big of a deal, right?

503
00:27:36.705 --> 00:27:39.000
[LAUGH]
>> Then there are some,

504
00:27:39.000 --> 00:27:41.420
are there some frameworks
that we can look at?

505
00:27:41.420 --> 00:27:44.750
Like are there certain guidelines we
can follow for certain industries or?

506
00:27:44.750 --> 00:27:49.220
>> Well there's,
there's almost an endless sea of those and

507
00:27:49.220 --> 00:27:54.590
it would be almost, essentially
impossible to go through them all.

508
00:27:54.590 --> 00:27:56.590
But there's plenty of them out there.

509
00:27:56.590 --> 00:28:00.409
There's ones from ISO,
from ISA, or no ISO.

510
00:28:01.630 --> 00:28:04.760
There's ones from the federal government,

511
00:28:04.760 --> 00:28:07.720
there's ones from you
know different countries.

512
00:28:07.720 --> 00:28:12.540
You know there's so many of these
things that tell you processes

513
00:28:12.540 --> 00:28:17.440
to follow and have things included and
that pertain to this process.

514
00:28:17.440 --> 00:28:20.110
I mean you could look at stuff like Cobit,
for example.

515
00:28:20.110 --> 00:28:23.290
It's got stuff that relates to this plus.

516
00:28:23.290 --> 00:28:24.510
There's other ones out there, too.

517
00:28:24.510 --> 00:28:27.480
The question is which one pertains to you.

518
00:28:27.480 --> 00:28:31.820
If you're not in a regulated industry
then you have a little more latitude.

519
00:28:31.820 --> 00:28:35.060
So if you're not in one of those
aforementioned industries then there's

520
00:28:35.060 --> 00:28:37.630
additional, then there's
additional stuff out there for

521
00:28:37.630 --> 00:28:39.980
you too that you can be
a lot more broad on it.

522
00:28:39.980 --> 00:28:42.670
Most people like to follow at
least some sort of standard.

523
00:28:42.670 --> 00:28:45.860
Even if you're not regulated, they like
to follow at least some sort of standard.

524
00:28:45.860 --> 00:28:46.480
Because who knows?

525
00:28:46.480 --> 00:28:50.520
Maybe whatever you're doing today
catches the eye of someone else and

526
00:28:50.520 --> 00:28:52.950
they're saying we could work with you.

527
00:28:52.950 --> 00:28:58.310
We want to be able to do this and
you've got a solution.

528
00:28:58.310 --> 00:29:01.320
Maybe you never thought about
this combination of products and

529
00:29:01.320 --> 00:29:03.360
services happening but
what someone else did.

530
00:29:03.360 --> 00:29:04.540
They came to you.

531
00:29:04.540 --> 00:29:08.270
Now they need to be on the same page,
speak the same language as you.

532
00:29:08.270 --> 00:29:13.748
If you made your stuff up completely
from scratch, that's fine.

533
00:29:13.748 --> 00:29:15.100
It works great for you, but

534
00:29:15.100 --> 00:29:19.360
if you need to collaborate and
form part of a larger ecosystem.

535
00:29:19.360 --> 00:29:22.280
You are going to have to figure
ways to speak the same language.

536
00:29:22.280 --> 00:29:25.140
They are probably not going to
cut you too much slack on that.

537
00:29:25.140 --> 00:29:28.640
Especially when you start getting
the larger and larger contracts.

538
00:29:28.640 --> 00:29:31.530
If they invite you in,
they are responsible for you.

539
00:29:31.530 --> 00:29:35.290
They want to make sure you are speaking
that language and know what is going on.

540
00:29:35.290 --> 00:29:37.440
And if not, that may be enough to say,

541
00:29:37.440 --> 00:29:43.350
you can't participate on this because
you don't follow accepted guidelines.

542
00:29:43.350 --> 00:29:48.540
So most places will try to do something
at least as close as possible,

543
00:29:48.540 --> 00:29:51.940
just something like ISO, or
something that's fairly generic.

544
00:29:51.940 --> 00:29:57.670
Which can be clearly followed or related
to one of the other ones, but you don't

545
00:29:57.670 --> 00:30:01.480
necessarily always have that option of
just choosing what you want at the buffet.

546
00:30:01.480 --> 00:30:04.190
Sometimes you just gotta say,
this is what you're following.

547
00:30:04.190 --> 00:30:06.240
You're in this industry,
you're following this.

548
00:30:06.240 --> 00:30:07.430
Any questions?

549
00:30:07.430 --> 00:30:09.860
That's your choice, right there.

550
00:30:09.860 --> 00:30:13.030
So you definitely need to be
thinking about all those.

551
00:30:13.030 --> 00:30:16.180
>> All right, well a lot of great
information again about that risk analysis

552
00:30:16.180 --> 00:30:17.900
process.

553
00:30:17.900 --> 00:30:19.750
Any closing words on this one?

554
00:30:21.000 --> 00:30:24.470
>> No, I think that's kind
of like the big part of it.

555
00:30:24.470 --> 00:30:28.030
If you understand that process, and

556
00:30:28.030 --> 00:30:32.680
actually let me do expand this out
a bit now that I think about it.

557
00:30:32.680 --> 00:30:38.330
If you are someone that's been through
stuff like the A+ Net+ Security+, or

558
00:30:38.330 --> 00:30:41.660
anything like that, we hadn't even talked
about that in our forensics course, and

559
00:30:41.660 --> 00:30:42.400
stuff like that.

560
00:30:44.060 --> 00:30:46.940
There are different frameworks
that are mentioned,

561
00:30:46.940 --> 00:30:49.800
there are different steps that come in in
different ways of doing risk assessment,

562
00:30:49.800 --> 00:30:55.840
so this can get really big really quickly.

563
00:30:55.840 --> 00:30:58.650
But, you will find it pretty much
follows the same type of procedure,

564
00:30:58.650 --> 00:31:00.510
like a standard procedure.

565
00:31:00.510 --> 00:31:03.155
I would tell you if you've been
through the other Com J Exams: A+,

566
00:31:03.155 --> 00:31:05.757
Net+, Security+, you're probably
in pretty good shape as far

567
00:31:05.757 --> 00:31:07.970
as understanding the risk
assessment process.

568
00:31:07.970 --> 00:31:10.310
They're just adding some
more meat on to it.

569
00:31:10.310 --> 00:31:13.720
So give you that little skeleton
they had and the other courses.

570
00:31:13.720 --> 00:31:14.580
That's a good thing.

571
00:31:14.580 --> 00:31:17.230
Especially if you been through Security+.

572
00:31:17.230 --> 00:31:18.830
They've given you that,

573
00:31:18.830 --> 00:31:23.585
we're just adding more meat on to it
here so you're already on a good track.

574
00:31:23.585 --> 00:31:25.180
>> Good.

575
00:31:25.180 --> 00:31:26.960
Well, ladies and gentlemen,
that's going to do it for this one.

576
00:31:26.960 --> 00:31:29.320
Signing off for ITProTV, I'm Mike Rodrick.

577
00:31:29.320 --> 00:31:32.595
>> And I'm Sean Oriyano
>> And we'll see you next time.

>> Yeah that's where you gotta enter this

take a look at it from from far away and

pieces of the beast to kinda see

17
00:00:49.900 --> 00:00:55.880
Because this is, I'll tell you,
doing policies, procedures, audits, for

the most part I look at it as myself, it's

00:01:14.850 --> 00:01:16.810

it, they're waiting for
the bad stuff to happen.

00:01:20.770 --> 00:01:26.030
It's not if, it's just a question
of when it's going to occur.

26
00:01:26.030 --> 00:01:30.630
So policies, procedures are supposed
to put something in place to

00:01:30.630 --> 00:01:35.700

at least reduce it as much as possible.

28
00:01:35.700 --> 00:01:38.300

00:01:38.300 --> 00:01:43.180
I mean, what is that, why, as a company,

>> Well, what happens is,
if you look at them,

they're partially giving you a goal to aim

32
00:01:50.010 --> 00:01:52.820
I think of it as sometimes

33
00:01:52.820 --> 00:01:54.130
When you look at, so

you have that direction saying,
okay, this is our mission statement.

35
00:01:57.910 --> 00:01:59.550
This is what we're going for.

36
