And then you have ways,
as you get further down from that and

37
00:02:03.080 --> 00:02:08.760
getting into the weeds,
of actually accomplishing that task.

38
00:02:08.760 --> 00:02:13.340
>> Any large organization is gonna
have some sort of high level idea

00:02:13.340 --> 00:02:18.010

why security is important to them.

00:02:18.010 --> 00:02:20.420

because really a mission statement,

Considered marching orders,
we're gonna provide good customer service,

that's the mission statement.

45
00:02:33.350 --> 00:02:36.340
Well, it doesn't say how you're
gonna provide, it just says you are.

46
00:02:36.340 --> 00:02:41.430
So that's kind of part of the end
it covers, and then, like I said,

47
00:02:41.430 --> 00:02:45.210
it gets down into all the little details
of how each thing is gonna happen.

48
00:02:45.210 --> 00:02:46.770
So it gets implemented from there on out.

49
00:02:46.770 --> 00:02:51.240
And if you don't have it, you don't
have a goal you're going towards, or

00:02:51.240 --> 00:02:52.150
a mindset, or

00:02:52.150 --> 00:02:55.790
a motivation that's putting you that way,

00:03:01.540 --> 00:03:03.970

written one before.

00:03:03.970 --> 00:03:08.020

56
00:03:08.020 --> 00:03:12.580
>> Fortunately there's a lot of people

57
00:03:12.580 --> 00:03:16.460

had to get into policy development,

58
00:03:16.460 --> 00:03:18.550
or you've had very little
experience with it,

59
00:03:18.550 --> 00:03:22.325
fortunately there's a lot
of stuff to help you out.

60
00:03:22.325 --> 00:03:27.125

they, I mean the different industries,

61
00:03:27.125 --> 00:03:31.856
as well as different,
more generic organizations

00:03:32.907 --> 00:03:36.697
that are kind of non-profits and

00:03:41.207 --> 00:03:44.267
If you're in a regulated industry,
have some sort of legal requirement,

65
00:03:44.267 --> 00:03:46.963
then it's almost assured that
there's policies out there,

66
00:03:46.963 --> 00:03:48.513
in some cases they're just boilerplate.

67
00:03:48.513 --> 00:03:51.363
You just copy them, paste them in
your stuff, replace a few names,

68
00:03:51.363 --> 00:03:54.629
and there you go, and that's it.

69
00:03:54.629 --> 00:03:57.517
Other ones,
you will have to take the guidance,

70
00:03:57.517 --> 00:04:02.230
whatever that standards body puts out and
then you have to take it and kind of

71
00:04:02.230 --> 00:04:07.220
build your own policy that covers the same
thing but customized to your situation.

72
00:04:07.220 --> 00:04:10.370
And, in a few cases, yes you will
have to write them from scratch,

73
00:04:10.370 --> 00:04:12.618
we really don't have any choice.

74
00:04:12.618 --> 00:04:16.600
But, like I said, the fortunate thing on
it is, is that get into policy when you

75

316
00:18:16.670 --> 00:18:19.645

00:18:24.140 --> 00:18:27.620

00:18:43.940 --> 00:18:48.850

00:18:48.850 --> 00:18:50.760

325
00:18:50.760 --> 00:18:55.210

have program, then we have procedures.

326
00:18:55.210 --> 00:18:59.460

accordance with certain baselines and

327
00:18:59.460 --> 00:19:05.710

assisted by having our guidelines

328
00:19:05.710 --> 00:19:10.070

00:19:10.070 --> 00:19:16.070

they're gonna be a number of them

mandatory vacation all the time.

00:19:34.620 --> 00:19:36.300

orientation procedures, NDAs,

00:19:45.560 --> 00:19:49.390

be built into different processes and

multiple times and multiple places.

>> Very good.

00:09:38.010 --> 00:09:41.580

00:09:41.580 --> 00:09:42.820
But yeah.
That's absolutely true.

00:09:42.820 --> 00:09:45.960

00:09:45.960 --> 00:09:47.720

there's been a lot of discussion on that.

00:09:53.550 --> 00:09:57.700
Whether it's a fingerprint or

00:09:57.700 --> 00:10:03.800
So there's ways to do it,
to tie it back to you and bind it to you.

183
00:10:03.800 --> 00:10:09.972
It's more likely gonna be ultimately
based around something that's biometric,

184
00:10:09.972 --> 00:10:14.990
but the thing is is that even though

something that, heck, you should have

00:19:24.750 --> 00:19:26.830

00:20:19.058 --> 00:20:22.730
I think it's not the most

00:20:25.480 --> 00:20:29.850

00:21:40.310 --> 00:21:43.260
>> So and I know you've already mentioned

they're looking at you as someone

00:22:06.590 --> 00:22:09.375
So if they're pushing you up

00:22:09.375 --> 00:22:13.006
they do kind of expect you to have some
sort of experience or knowledge or

00:22:13.006 --> 00:22:16.170
whatever, fluency,
whatever it needs to get that job done.

00:22:16.170 --> 00:22:21.990
So they may have you do that or

00:22:21.990 --> 00:22:25.840
something to do that, but then again,
that's not always ideal for

the same reasons that we don't always

testers because they're not always going

00:22:49.070 --> 00:22:52.820
So it's not unheard of to
use either of those or

00:22:55.020 --> 00:23:01.010

00:23:04.198 --> 00:23:07.852
Okay, these are additional things to

00:23:07.852 --> 00:23:11.279
beyond because we don't want to face

398
00:23:11.279 --> 00:23:12.219
>> All right, well, good.

00:23:12.219 --> 00:23:15.673
All right, well, auditing,

00:23:15.673 --> 00:23:18.396

I take it as they're very

00:24:18.200 --> 00:24:20.690

00:24:32.930 --> 00:24:38.020

00:26:39.025 --> 00:26:40.380

episodes.description: An incident is an event that's not planned for outside of normal operations or something that disrupts those normal operations. Viewers will hear some examples of incident response frameworks in place, some steps involved, and the importance of having it in place before an incident occurs.

Statistically it's

00:07:34.030 --> 00:07:39.053

00:07:55.604 --> 00:07:59.830
So if it comes back They've got the stuff

00:08:18.250 --> 00:08:23.250

00:08:38.060 --> 00:08:41.070

00:08:41.070 --> 00:08:44.020
After they said it was just

00:08:48.040 --> 00:08:51.320

00:08:51.320 --> 00:08:55.270

00:08:55.270 --> 00:08:59.970
also in case we do have anything

00:08:59.970 --> 00:09:02.900
we're just gonna proactively

So, those guys did that, but

where if they had someone

what have you, they had the ability

00:09:20.260 --> 00:09:25.590

00:09:25.590 --> 00:09:29.120
what they looked at to see if there

00:09:29.120 --> 00:09:30.910
They had all sorts of things, and

00:09:30.910 --> 00:09:34.460
that was a legal requirement

00:09:34.460 --> 00:09:37.370

00:09:37.370 --> 00:09:40.460

00:09:40.460 --> 00:09:43.440
The FDIC and all those ones came in, and

00:09:43.440 --> 00:09:48.170

00:09:48.170 --> 00:09:50.330

00:09:55.450 --> 00:09:59.160
There's other places too that have

I think of stuff like most militaries,

episodes.description: It's important to stay on top of the latest and best information out there and Global Information Awareness is a way to do that. In response to collective security threats, an increasing number of groups and communities have been created to share information that will expose people to new viewpoints, new technologies, and new techniques other people are using to become better informed how to solve different security issues. and you've got command of it,

405
00:23:51.730 --> 00:23:53.700
you've proven it through certification.

406
00:23:53.700 --> 00:23:56.938
So good plus for you, you've done that,
that's what we wanna see.

407
00:23:56.938 --> 00:24:01.610
But if you've gone ahead and got

408
00:24:01.610 --> 00:24:05.622
a certification that no one knows what it
is, and you have to explain who that is,

409
00:24:05.622 --> 00:24:10.660
[LAUGH] then, and what the acronym means,
it's like well what is that?

410
00:24:10.660 --> 00:24:14.910
Okay, there's a vendor
that's still around.

411
00:24:14.910 --> 00:24:16.620
Security Certified?

412
00:24:16.620 --> 00:24:21.530
They've been around for a while,
and they were a bigger name, but

413
00:24:21.530 --> 00:24:23.700
their marketing wasn't as great.

414
00:24:23.700 --> 00:24:25.270
I've got their certification.

415
00:24:25.270 --> 00:24:26.660
It's very good information.

416
00:24:26.660 --> 00:24:30.720
I wouldn't ding them one bit for
their information.

417
00:24:30.720 --> 00:24:33.730
Because they cover a lot of stuff,
in a very unique way.

418
00:24:33.730 --> 00:24:37.650
They do everything in there
course on Window's and on Linux.

419
00:24:37.650 --> 00:24:40.060
Which is almost unheard of to see it
[INAUDIBLE] okay, this is how you do it.

420
00:24:40.060 --> 00:24:41.020
This side and this side.

421
00:24:41.020 --> 00:24:43.690
So you're getting exposure to
both whether you like it or not.

422
00:24:43.690 --> 00:24:45.200
You will know how to do
both sides of the house.

423
00:24:45.200 --> 00:24:46.540
That's really cool.

424
00:24:46.540 --> 00:24:50.156
But, mention Security Certified to
someone and see if they know it.

425
00:24:50.156 --> 00:24:53.600
So holding that certification
would be kinda something,

426
00:24:53.600 --> 00:24:54.660
that's gonna help you out.

427
00:24:54.660 --> 00:24:57.530
When ever I say Security Certified,
it's like oh, I got Security Certified.

428
00:24:57.530 --> 00:24:58.230
In what?

429
00:24:58.230 --> 00:24:59.912
No that 's the name of the certification.

430
00:24:59.912 --> 00:25:00.460
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH].

431
00:25:00.460 --> 00:25:03.170
It is, what it is.

432
00:25:03.170 --> 00:25:05.448
So, that's the thing you gotta look for.

433
00:25:05.448 --> 00:25:07.893
Certifications will come as part of that.

434
00:25:07.893 --> 00:25:12.130
>> Alright well, I'll tell you what,
a lot of great information there, Sean.

435
00:25:12.130 --> 00:25:15.250
We're just about out of time,
anything else you want to talk about?

436
00:25:15.250 --> 00:25:17.680
>> No, I think they've probably
heard me talk long enough.

437
00:25:17.680 --> 00:25:19.295
They're like,
when are gonna go to the next stuff?

438
00:25:19.295 --> 00:25:21.090
>> [LAUGH]
>> So I think we're good on that,

439
00:25:21.090 --> 00:25:22.600
they've got the point across.

440
00:25:22.600 --> 00:25:23.640
>> Alright, very good.

441
00:25:23.640 --> 00:25:25.960
Well ladies and gentlemen,
that's gonna do it for this episode.

442
00:25:25.960 --> 00:25:28.190
Signing off for ITProTV, I'm Mike Rodrick.

443
00:25:28.190 --> 00:25:29.140
>> And I'm Sean Oriyano.

444
00:25:29.140 --> 00:25:31.154
>> And we'll see you next time.

445
00:25:31.154 --> 00:25:34.138

episodes.description: Bringing in contractors into an enterprise environment can have some potential difficulties when it comes to following company policies, procedures, rules, and regulations. episodes.title: Working with Contractors
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:01.562 --> 00:00:10.328
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10.328 --> 00:00:12.824
Hello and
welcome to another episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:12.824 --> 00:00:13.324
I'm your host Michael Roderick.

4
00:00:14.370 --> 00:00:16.870
With me today is Sean Oriyano,
how you doing Sean?

5
00:00:16.870 --> 00:00:18.500
>> Doing pretty good, how you doing?

6
00:00:18.500 --> 00:00:19.440
>> I am doing great.

7
00:00:19.440 --> 00:00:21.954
We've got another exciting
episode coming your way in our

8
00:00:21.954 --> 00:00:24.172
CompTIA Advanced Security Practitioner
series.

9
00:00:24.172 --> 00:00:28.253
This morning we're gonna take a look at
working with contracts and contractors.

10
00:00:28.253 --> 00:00:30.990
Sounds like a whole lot of fun Sean.

11
00:00:30.990 --> 00:00:33.300
>> Yeah.
>> [LAUGH]

12
00:00:33.300 --> 00:00:35.680
>> It's something that has definitely got

13
00:00:35.680 --> 00:00:38.920
a set of concerns all its own over

14
00:00:40.020 --> 00:00:43.610
just about almost everything
else we've talked about.

15
00:00:43.610 --> 00:00:46.330
That's why we have to
really talk about this and

16
00:00:46.330 --> 00:00:52.270
where a CASP fits in with dealing
with outside contractors and vendors.

17
00:00:52.270 --> 00:00:55.550
Because that's the way the world works and
period.

18
00:00:55.550 --> 00:00:59.490
You're gonna be, no matter what segment
you're in, if you're producing a product,

19
00:00:59.490 --> 00:01:03.880
unless it's a very simple product or
something of that nature, you're probably

20
00:01:03.880 --> 00:01:09.080
gonna have to outsource work, or
parts, or whatever to someone else.

21
00:01:09.080 --> 00:01:13.980
Or if you're service related
type situation, you may need to

22
00:01:13.980 --> 00:01:18.900
bring in people from the outside to help
you support whatever it is you're doing.

23
00:01:18.900 --> 00:01:21.310
So the question here comes in for

24
00:01:21.310 --> 00:01:27.080
a CASP is, how do you deal with
the unique security requirements

25
00:01:27.080 --> 00:01:31.380
of people coming in from outside your
organization and working with you.

26
00:01:31.380 --> 00:01:34.050
>> Right cuz these are people that
haven't been through my training, or

27
00:01:34.050 --> 00:01:39.530
haven't been assigned my EULA,
and things like that, right?

28
00:01:39.530 --> 00:01:41.010
Which can cause a problem.

29
00:01:41.010 --> 00:01:43.720
>> Yeah, that's really it.

30
00:01:43.720 --> 00:01:46.750
There's a potential problem lurking there,
or

31
00:01:46.750 --> 00:01:49.270
it could be a potential
problem lurking there.

32
00:01:49.270 --> 00:01:52.004
Because those people definitely coming in
from the outside, they're not your people.

33
00:01:52.004 --> 00:01:52.850
You know they're just not.

34
00:01:55.050 --> 00:02:00.758
So what can you do to make sure that
the contract that you're responsible for

35
00:02:00.758 --> 00:02:06.466
or the product you're producing,
meets the standards you've set forth,

36
00:02:06.466 --> 00:02:11.104
and is being kept under a certain
secrecy and stuff like that,

37
00:02:11.104 --> 00:02:13.893
if those people don't work for you?

38
00:02:13.893 --> 00:02:18.393
So that's something that we're dealing
with here, and something that a lot of

39
00:02:18.393 --> 00:02:22.765
you, watching this have already dealt
with, in some way shape or form.

40
00:02:22.765 --> 00:02:24.595
It's not easy.

41
00:02:24.595 --> 00:02:28.675
Sometimes, managing a third party, or

42
00:02:28.675 --> 00:02:33.355
external party,
to help you get a project done, let's say,

43
00:02:33.355 --> 00:02:39.880
let's put this in terms of one
of the situations you'll see.

44
00:02:39.880 --> 00:02:44.920
It's not uncommon to have a company
get a government contract, let's say,

45
00:02:44.920 --> 00:02:49.801
they get a government contract, now
when they have that government contract,

46
00:02:49.801 --> 00:02:55.780
they say, well, I don't have the manpower
to do it on my own, so I'm gonna go out

47
00:02:55.780 --> 00:03:01.520
to someone else to help me with it, and
that person may be getting contractors.

48
00:03:01.520 --> 00:03:04.250
You see that sort of thing.

49
00:03:04.250 --> 00:03:09.855
So, now you've got a situation
where I"m the prime contractor for,

50
00:03:09.855 --> 00:03:12.800
let's say, the government.

51
00:03:12.800 --> 00:03:15.800
And I need to go to someone else
that got the people for me,

52
00:03:15.800 --> 00:03:17.090
like an employment agency.

53
00:03:17.090 --> 00:03:19.200
I needed more whatever.

54
00:03:19.200 --> 00:03:20.532
So, they had to go find those people.

55
00:03:20.532 --> 00:03:24.956
So now I have requirements that
were imposed upon me when I won

56
00:03:24.956 --> 00:03:29.576
the contract that I must follow,
or suffer the consequences.

57
00:03:29.576 --> 00:03:33.656
And then I've got to make sure that that
person that I'm going to, or agency that

58
00:03:33.656 --> 00:03:37.740
I'm going to, that's grabbing people for
me to help me fulfill this contract,

59
00:03:37.740 --> 00:03:40.921
I need to make sure that they meet
those requirements as well and

60
00:03:40.921 --> 00:03:44.854
are upholding them, and the people that
come in from their are reading that.

61
00:03:44.854 --> 00:03:48.452
Because there's a whole chain of
responsibility happening there.

62
00:03:48.452 --> 00:03:51.053
There's certain standards that
must be met across the board.

63
00:03:51.053 --> 00:03:55.860
And if they're not met, it can keep
flowing uphill all the way to the person

64
00:03:55.860 --> 00:04:00.363
that's the prime has to answer for
it and they're not gonna be happy if

65
00:04:00.363 --> 00:04:05.930
something happens and they're the ones
that are left with egg on their face.

66
00:04:05.930 --> 00:04:09.800
They may cut you loose as the outsourcer
but they're the ones that are going to

67
00:04:09.800 --> 00:04:13.860
suffer the damage in a lot of cases and
that's not where they want to be.

68
00:04:13.860 --> 00:04:17.210
And not where you want to be either
because if you're the one that

69
00:04:17.210 --> 00:04:19.550
did something dumb or

70
00:04:19.550 --> 00:04:23.550
didn't adhere to certain standards,
you may not work in that industry again.

71
00:04:23.550 --> 00:04:24.720
It's been known to happen.

72
00:04:24.720 --> 00:04:26.390
I know in the government's side,

73
00:04:28.160 --> 00:04:31.370
because of the way people
are registered in the system and

74
00:04:31.370 --> 00:04:36.400
kept track of in the system, if you fail
to fulfill the contract, that's on record.

75
00:04:36.400 --> 00:04:38.300
Someone else can look at that later on and
say,

76
00:04:38.300 --> 00:04:42.730
well this person did
something bone-headed.

77
00:04:42.730 --> 00:04:45.300
Or, had a contract pulled from them and

78
00:04:45.300 --> 00:04:49.370
awarded to someone else
because of compliance issues.

79
00:04:49.370 --> 00:04:53.500
That could very well just take you
completely out of the game permanently.

80
00:04:53.500 --> 00:04:54.820
It's been know to happen.

81
00:04:54.820 --> 00:04:56.770
You get blacklisted, you're out.

82
00:04:56.770 --> 00:05:01.400
So we need to make sure these things
are upheld both for our pocketbook and

83
00:05:01.400 --> 00:05:03.330
our continued well being.

84
00:05:03.330 --> 00:05:07.700
If we want to work In that environment or

85
00:05:07.700 --> 00:05:12.410
that industry segment that
we're in at the current time.

86
00:05:12.410 --> 00:05:13.540
>> All right, so

87
00:05:13.540 --> 00:05:16.540
working with partners is one of the things
that we're gonna have to deal with.

88
00:05:16.540 --> 00:05:20.090
Our organization is probably not isolated,
we're not an island.

89
00:05:20.090 --> 00:05:22.460
So we've got partner businesses
that we have to work with.

90
00:05:22.460 --> 00:05:27.630
>> Yeah, the more complex whatever it is
you're doing, the more complex it is,

91
00:05:27.630 --> 00:05:35.120
unique it is and larger the scale gets,
all of a sudden what happens is you

92
00:05:35.120 --> 00:05:38.210
run into a situation where you probably
can't do the whole thing yourself.

93
00:05:38.210 --> 00:05:42.730
And that could be a case of,
like in the example I was using,

94
00:05:42.730 --> 00:05:47.270
you have to go to an outside agency that
in turn hires the people in for you, and

95
00:05:47.270 --> 00:05:51.310
vets them, and checks them, or
at least they have them on their list.

96
00:05:51.310 --> 00:05:55.190
It can be that, or
it can be a situation where you got,

97
00:05:55.190 --> 00:05:59.540
let's say you're building
something like an aircraft.

98
00:05:59.540 --> 00:06:03.049
That's one from aerospace near and
dear to my heart, I know that one.

99
00:06:04.640 --> 00:06:09.190
So you're building a new aircraft,
let's say.

100
00:06:09.190 --> 00:06:13.950
You're not doing that on your own,
unless you're talking a very,

101
00:06:13.950 --> 00:06:15.170
very, very small aircraft.

102
00:06:15.170 --> 00:06:17.226
Probably what they call RC aircraft.

103
00:06:17.226 --> 00:06:19.881
>> [LAUGH]
>> If you're building aircraft now days,

104
00:06:19.881 --> 00:06:22.160
you ain't doing it on your own.

105
00:06:22.160 --> 00:06:23.830
It just ain't happening.

106
00:06:23.830 --> 00:06:26.590
And I'm talking even the private aircraft.

107
00:06:26.590 --> 00:06:29.770
When you get the smaller ones like that.

108
00:06:29.770 --> 00:06:30.590
Those ones aren't built.

109
00:06:30.590 --> 00:06:34.070
Cessna does not go out and
build a whole aircraft on their own.

110
00:06:34.070 --> 00:06:36.180
They have stuff that
they're responsible for,

111
00:06:36.180 --> 00:06:38.830
and they provide certain
skills themselves in house.

112
00:06:38.830 --> 00:06:43.580
But the parts come from many
different people to make that.

113
00:06:43.580 --> 00:06:46.480
From the engine, to the seats,
to the instrumentation,

114
00:06:46.480 --> 00:06:52.122
all those things
are provided by outsourcers.

115
00:06:52.122 --> 00:06:53.190
And so they order them from their and
bring those parts in.

116
00:06:53.190 --> 00:06:58.290
You're talking a pretty complex
mechanism and a lot of things revolving

117
00:06:58.290 --> 00:07:01.730
around that need to happen to make sure
that thing is completed successfully.

118
00:07:01.730 --> 00:07:08.850
And in this case it's airborne,
so it can be a big daunting task.

119
00:07:08.850 --> 00:07:11.010
What you're gonna do is
you're going to for yourself,

120
00:07:11.010 --> 00:07:14.760
I mean one of the things we talked about
during this whole CASP stuff is we talked

121
00:07:14.760 --> 00:07:18.900
about, putting policies and procedures and
standards and all that stuff in place.

122
00:07:18.900 --> 00:07:19.910
Hopefully you've done all that.

123
00:07:19.910 --> 00:07:21.196
If you haven't then it's probably not,

124
00:07:21.196 --> 00:07:24.400
[LAUGH] you're probably not ready to
go out to your outside contractor yet.

125
00:07:24.400 --> 00:07:27.630
If you are gonna work with
an outside party, one of the things,

126
00:07:27.630 --> 00:07:32.120
and I know, I see some of the comments
here in the chatroom, and

127
00:07:32.120 --> 00:07:34.890
I know we've had people in
the past that work in that space.

128
00:07:34.890 --> 00:07:36.480
I work in that space too.

129
00:07:36.480 --> 00:07:40.700
As far as working as
an outside contractor and

130
00:07:40.700 --> 00:07:46.070
working as a contractor directly,
I know that environment too.

131
00:07:46.070 --> 00:07:50.370
And I know there's
variations of contracts.

132
00:07:50.370 --> 00:07:52.530
There's many different
forms they can come in.

133
00:07:52.530 --> 00:07:55.051
Different regulations they can place
on them and different requirements.

134
00:07:55.051 --> 00:07:57.861
It could be an endless sea of doing stuff.

135
00:07:57.861 --> 00:08:02.123
That's why you gotta hire people to
even read those contracts the right way.

136
00:08:02.123 --> 00:08:08.177
So, once you've got that and you order
the contract, and you meet the standard,

137
00:08:08.177 --> 00:08:12.652
if you decide to subcontract any
of that work to anyone else,

138
00:08:12.652 --> 00:08:15.770
there's requirements placed on that.

139
00:08:15.770 --> 00:08:19.230
Basically the person you're
contracting with says, you want to use

140
00:08:19.230 --> 00:08:23.530
an outside party to do this if they
allow it, which they usually do.

141
00:08:23.530 --> 00:08:28.050
What they'll say is, go ahead,
you've been awarded the contract,

142
00:08:28.050 --> 00:08:30.070
you know how much money you're making.

143
00:08:30.070 --> 00:08:31.720
You know what the requirements are.

144
00:08:31.720 --> 00:08:35.000
And you have to make sure they
make those requirements too.

145
00:08:35.000 --> 00:08:39.490
And now you have to meet those
requirements of keeping stuff safe and

146
00:08:39.490 --> 00:08:41.620
secret and all that type of stuff.

147
00:08:41.620 --> 00:08:43.640
It also has to be certain
performance guidelines.

148
00:08:43.640 --> 00:08:45.540
So you take their stuff,
put it in your stuff and

149
00:08:45.540 --> 00:08:48.240
hand this that whole collective stuff,
thing.

150
00:08:48.240 --> 00:08:51.520
If it doesn't meet those standards, we're
not going to them, we're going to you.

151
00:08:51.520 --> 00:08:54.540
You know, you're the ones responsible.

152
00:08:54.540 --> 00:08:58.690
You know, you're working on some
classified project and that subcontract

153
00:08:58.690 --> 00:09:04.410
has someone that is deciding to sell those
secrets to another country and what have

154
00:09:04.410 --> 00:09:09.250
you, they're gonna get everyone up that
whole food chain go, how did that happen?

155
00:09:09.250 --> 00:09:13.260
There's gonna be, not a head rolled,
there's gonna be several heads rolled

156
00:09:13.260 --> 00:09:16.515
at the outsourcer and
you that are gonna pay for that.

157
00:09:16.515 --> 00:09:21.810
So it can be a pretty big situation,
so you need to make sure you have

158
00:09:21.810 --> 00:09:25.310
your standards adhered to, you need make
sure, you need to know what the standards

159
00:09:25.310 --> 00:09:29.090
that the person that's giving you
that work wants you to adhere to.

160
00:09:29.090 --> 00:09:32.540
And they'll establish what standards
those people need to have applied to them

161
00:09:32.540 --> 00:09:33.940
as well, if you're gonna get them.

162
00:09:33.940 --> 00:09:38.120
And what you'll do to also make sure that
that's being done they have a process

163
00:09:38.120 --> 00:09:41.380
called, really it's easy to
figure out what's happening,

164
00:09:41.380 --> 00:09:43.740
called a document exchange and review.

165
00:09:43.740 --> 00:09:47.340
Which is where you'll provide some
documentation to the person you've chosen

166
00:09:47.340 --> 00:09:51.740
after you've got them under a NDA or
a non-compete or both.

167
00:09:51.740 --> 00:09:54.270
You'll give them the relevant documents,

168
00:09:54.270 --> 00:09:58.380
tell them this is what I
need you to be able to do.

169
00:09:58.380 --> 00:10:02.104
And then they'll provide documents to you
saying these are the current things we

170
00:10:02.104 --> 00:10:02.660
adhere to.

171
00:10:02.660 --> 00:10:07.060
And they'll give you some folders or
documents and all that.

172
00:10:07.060 --> 00:10:11.520
And saying, here's what we have, here's
what you have, how far apart are we,

173
00:10:11.520 --> 00:10:15.330
and what can we do to make sure
that we're both on the same page,

174
00:10:15.330 --> 00:10:19.790
and meet the standard,
and can work together?

175
00:10:19.790 --> 00:10:23.370
>> So are there particular procedures
we should go through when we're trying

176
00:10:23.370 --> 00:10:27.140
to find somebody to work with or
to outsource to or?

177
00:10:27.140 --> 00:10:30.020
>> Yes,
there are definite procedures for it and

178
00:10:30.020 --> 00:10:34.490
this is again one of those cases
where your mileage may vary.

179
00:10:34.490 --> 00:10:40.140
It depends on the specific requirements of
the person that's giving you that work,

180
00:10:40.140 --> 00:10:43.980
or if it's you giving the work to someone
else, there's no one up above you,

181
00:10:43.980 --> 00:10:48.130
then you can have more latitude on that.

182
00:10:48.130 --> 00:10:49.960
If it's the case that you're working for
someone else, and

183
00:10:49.960 --> 00:10:53.130
you're subcontracting that out then

184

they'll kick your butt right there

take notes and

I know I'm using the military

00:14:08.769 --> 00:14:13.749

00:14:21.725 --> 00:14:23.854
>> That's actually a very,

00:14:29.186 --> 00:14:31.692

00:14:37.015 --> 00:14:40.683
But if the project is sufficiently large,
where you have a lot of,

00:14:44.829 --> 00:14:49.448

00:18:56.905 --> 00:18:59.050
You can't sit there and

This is gonna be just generic

So we wanna make sure that when that

00:03:01.950 --> 00:03:05.150

53
00:03:05.150 --> 00:03:07.880

And as environments grow in size and

20 years later grew out of it finally.

70
00:04:01.955 --> 00:04:03.335
>> [LAUGH] I'm glad you

00:04:03.335 --> 00:04:08.955
>> I've developed new

00:04:11.035 --> 00:04:14.085

the reason why this process is in place,

00:04:45.340 --> 00:04:48.370
To get it up to someone

So while it may look like a good

they knew how to change over to the new

you just walk in the front
